==Literature== {{Main|Literary realism}} Broadly defined as "the faithful representation of reality",<ref>{{cite web|author=Donna M. Campbell |url=http://www.wsu.edu/~campbelld/amlit/realism.htm |title=Realism in American Literature |publisher=Wsu.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> Realism as a literary movement was based on "[[objective reality]]." It focused on showing everyday activities and life, primarily among the middle or lower class society, without romantic idealization or dramatization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Realism |title=Realism definition of Realism in the Free Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> It may be regarded as the general attempt to depict subjects as they are considered to exist in third person [[objective reality]], without embellishment or interpretation and "in accordance with secular, [[empirical]] rules."<ref>in so far as such subjects are "explicable in terms of natural causation without resort to supernatural or divine intervention" [[#refMorris2003|Morris, 2003]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=MFAW6dh24ZwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=realism&ei=ROOkS_LBA5TszASD95nXCA&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false p. 5]</ref> As such, the approach inherently implies a belief that such [[reality]] is [[ontological]]ly independent of human kind's conceptual schemes, linguistic practices and beliefs, and thus can be known (or knowable) to the artist, who can in turn represent this 'reality' faithfully. As [[Ian Watt]] states, modern realism "begins from the position that truth can be discovered by the individual through the senses" and as such "it has its origins in [[Descartes]] and [[John Locke|Locke]], and received its first full formulation by [[Thomas Reid]] in the middle of the eighteenth century."<ref>[[#refWatt1957|Watt, 1957]], p. 12</ref>
While the preceding [[Romantic era]] was also a reaction against the values of the [[Industrial Revolution]], realism was in its turn a reaction to romanticism, and for this reason it is also commonly derogatorily referred as "traditional" "bourgeois realism".<ref name="Barth79Replenishment"/> Some writers of [[Victorian literature]] produced works of realism.<ref>{{cite web|title=Victorian Literature|url=http://www.online-literature.com/periods/victorian.php|publisher=The Literature Network|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> The rigidities, conventions, and other limitations of "bourgeois realism," prompted in their turn the revolt later labeled as [[Modernist literature|modernism]]; starting around 1900, the driving motive of modernist literature was the criticism of the 19th-century bourgeois social order and world view, which was countered with an antirationalist, antirealist and antibourgeois program.<ref name="Barth79Replenishment">[[John Barth]] (1979) ''[[The Literature of Replenishment]]'', later republished in ''[[The Friday Book]]' '(1984).</ref><ref name="Graff75">[[Gerald Graff]] (1975) ''Babbitt at the Abyss: The Social Context of Postmodern. American Fiction'', [[TriQuarterly]], No. 33 (Spring 1975), pp. 307–37; reprinted in Putz and Freese, eds., Postmodernism and American Literature.</ref><ref name="Graff73">[[Gerald Graff]] (1973) ''The Myth of the Postmodernist Breakthrough'', [[TriQuarterly]], 26 (Winter, 1973) 383–417; rept in ''The Novel Today: Contemporary Writers on Modern Fiction Malcolm Bradbury'', ed., (London: Fontana, 1977); reprinted in Proza Nowa Amerykanska, ed., Szice Krytyczne (Warsaw, 1984); reprinted in ''Postmodernism in American Literature: A Critical Anthology'', Manfred Putz and Peter Freese, eds., (Darmstadt: Thesen Verlag, 1984), 58–81.</ref>
==Theatre== {{Main|Theatrical realism}} Theatrical realism is said to have first emerged in European drama in the 19th century as an offshoot of the [[Industrial Revolution]] and the age of science.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Our Dramatic Heritage, Volume 6|last=Hill|first=Philip|publisher=Associated University Presses|year=1992|isbn=978-0838634219|location=Cranbury, NJ|page=9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Making of Theatre History|last=Kuritz|first=Paul|publisher=Prentice Hall|year=1988|isbn=978-0135478615|location=Englewood Cliffs, NJ|page=305}}</ref> Some also specifically cited the invention of photography as the basis of the realist theater<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Art of Theatre: A Concise Introduction, 3rd edition|last=Downs|first=William|last2=Wright|first2=Lou Anne|last3=Ramsey|first3=Erik|publisher=Wadsworth Cengage Learning|year=2013|isbn=978-1111348311|location=Boston, MA|page=244}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Theatre Histories: An Introduction, 2nd edition|last=Zarrilli|first=Phillip|last2=McConachie|first2=Bruce|last3=Williams|first3=Gary Jay|last4=Sorgenfrei|first4=Carol|publisher=Routledge|year=2010|isbn=978-0415462235|location=Oxon|page=389}}</ref> while others view that the association between realism and drama is far older as demonstrated by the principles of dramatic forms such as the presentation of the physical world that closely matches reality.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Contemporary British Drama|last=Lane|first=David|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|year=2010|isbn=978-0748638215|location=Edinburgh|page=7}}</ref>
The achievement of realism in the [[theatre]] was to direct attention to the social and psychological problems of ordinary life. In its dramas, people emerge as victims of forces larger than themselves, as individuals confronted with a rapidly accelerating world.<ref>Simard, Rodney. ''Postmodern Drama: Contemporary Playwrights in America and Britain.'' New York: UP of America, 1984.</ref> These pioneering playwrights were unafraid to present their characters as ordinary, impotent, and unable to arrive at answers to their predicaments. This type of art represents what we see with our human eyes. [[Anton Chekhov|Anton Chekov]], for instance, used camera works to reproduce an uninflected [[slice of life]], exposing the rhetorical and suasive character of realistic theatricality.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Modern Drama and the Rhetoric of Theater|last=Worthen|first=W.B.|publisher=University of California Press|year=1992|isbn=978-0520286870|location=Berkeley, CA|page=194}}</ref> Scholars such as Thomas Postlewait noted that throughout the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, there were numerous joinings of [[melodrama]]tic and realistic forms and functions, which could be demonstrated in the way melodramatic elements existed in realistic forms and vice versa.<ref>{{Cite book|title=American Theatre|last=Saxon|first=Theresa|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0748645206|location=Edinburgh|page=146}}</ref>
In the United States, realism in drama preceded fictional realism by about two decades as theater historians identified the first impetus toward realism during the late 1870s and early 1880s.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=American Realism and American Drama, 1880–1940|last=Murphy|first=Brenda|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1987|isbn=978-0521327114|location=Cambridge|page=1}}</ref> Its development is also attributed to [[William Dean Howells]] and [[Henry James]] who served as the spokesmen for realism as well as articulator of its aesthetic principles.<ref name=":2" />
The realistic approach to theater collapsed into [[nihilism]] and the [[Absurdism|absurd]] after World War II.<ref name=":3" />
==Cinema== {{See also|Neorealism (art)|Poetic realism|Socialist realism}}
[[Italian Neorealism]] was a cinematic movement incorporating elements of realism that developed in post-WWII Italy. Notable Neorealists included [[Vittorio De Sica]], [[Luchino Visconti]], and [[Roberto Rossellini]]. Realist films generally focus on social issues.<ref>Hayward, Susan. "Realism" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. pp. 334–35</ref> There are two types of realism in film: seamless realism and aesthetic realism. Seamless realism tries to use narrative structures and film techniques to create a "reality effect" to maintain its [[authenticity (philosophy)|authenticity]].<ref>Hayward, Susan. "Realism" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. pp. 334–35</ref> Aesthetic realism, which was first called for by French filmmakers in the 1930s and promoted by [[Andre Bazin]] in the 1950s, acknowledges that a "film cannot be fixed to mean what it shows", as there are multiple realisms; as such, these filmmakers use location shooting, natural light and non-professional actors to ensure the viewer can make up her/his own choice based on the film, rather than being manipulated into a "preferred reading".<ref>Hayward, Susan. "Realism" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. pp. 334–35</ref> [[Siegfried Kracauer]] is also notable for arguing that realism is the most important function of cinema.<ref>[[Dudley Andrew]], ''The Major Film Theories: An Introduction'', Oxford, New York: Oxford University Press, 1976, Part II.</ref>
Aesthetic realist filmmakers use [[long shot]]s, [[deep focus]] and eye-level 90 degree shots to reduce manipulation of what the viewer sees.<ref>Hayward, Susan. "Realism" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. pp. 334–35</ref> Italian neorealism filmmakers from after WWII took the existing realist film approaches from France and Italy that emerged in the 1960s and used the to create a politically-oriented cinema. French filmmakers made some politically-oriented realist films in the 1960s, such as the [[cinéma vérité]] and documentary films of [[Jean Rouch]].<ref>Hayward, Susan. "Realism" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. pp. 334–35</ref> In the 1950s and 1960s, British, French and German new waves of filmmaking produced "slice-of-life" films (e.g., [[kitchen sink drama]]s in the UK).<ref>Hayward, Susan. "Realism" in ''Cinema Studies: The Key Concepts'' (Third Edition). Routledge, 2006. pp. 334–35</ref>
==Opera== {{main|Verismo}} Verismo was a post-Romantic operatic tradition associated with Italian composers such as [[Pietro Mascagni]], [[Ruggero Leoncavallo]], [[Umberto Giordano]], [[Francesco Cilea]] and [[Giacomo Puccini]]. They sought to bring the naturalism of influential late 19th-century writers such as [[Émile Zola]], [[Gustave Flaubert]], and [[Henrik Ibsen]] into opera. This new style presented true-to-life drama that featured gritty and flawed lower-class protagonists<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=A Chronology Of Western Classical Music 1600-2000|last=Paxman|first=Jon|publisher=Omnibus Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1783231218|location=London|pages=425–26}}</ref> while some described it as a heightened portrayal of a realistic event.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=A Tanner's Worth of Tune: Rediscovering the Post-war British Musical|last=Wright|first=Adrian|publisher=The Boydell Press|year=2010|isbn=978-1843835424|location=Suffolk, UK|page=139}}</ref> Although an account considered [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s ''[[Luisa Miller]]'' and ''[[La traviata|La Traviata]]'' as the first stirrings of the verismo,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Tosca|last=Carner|first=Mosco|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1993|isbn=978-0521228244|location=Cambridge|page=6}}</ref> some claimed that it began in 1890 with the first performance of [[Pietro Mascagni|Mascagni]]'s ''[[Cavalleria rusticana]]'', peaked in the early 1900s.<ref>"Verismo" in Stanley Sadie (ed.) ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music & Musicians'', London: Macmillan/New York: Grove, 1980, vol. 19 p. 670, {{ISBN|1561591742}}</ref> It was followed by Leoncavallo's Pagliacci, which dealt with the themes of infidelity, revenge, and violence.<ref name=":0" />
Verismo also reached Britain where pioneers included the [[Victorian era|Victorian-era]] theatrical partnership of the [[dramatist]] [[W. S. Gilbert]] and the composer [[Arthur Sullivan]] (1842–1900).<ref name=":1" /> Specifically, their play ''[[Iolanthe]]'' is considered a realistic representation of the nobility although it included fantastical elements.

{{Infobox TV advert |name=Revolving Door |image=Revolving Door ad screenshot.png |caption=A [[film frame|frame]] from ''Revolving Door'' |client=1988 George H.W. Bush presidential campaign|product=|agency=|director=|production company=|producer=|music= |released=October 5, 1988 |runtime= |language=[[English language|English]] |budget= |country= [[United States]] |preceded_by=|followed_by=|website=}} '''"Revolving Door"''' is a famous [[Attack ad|negative television commercial]] made for the [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988 United States Presidential Campaign]]. Along with the [[Willie Horton]] "Weekend Passes" advertisement, it is considered to be a prime factor in [[George H.W. Bush]]'s defeat of [[Michael Dukakis]]. The ad was produced by political consultant [[Roger Ailes]] with help by [[Lee Atwater]], and first aired on October 5, 1988. "Revolving door syndrome" is a term used in criminology to refer to [[recidivism]]; however, in the ad, the implication is that prison sentences were of an inconsequential length. ==Synopsis== The ad shows a line of convicts (portrayed by actors) casually walking in and out of a [[prison]] (filmed in [[Draper, Utah]]) by means of a [[revolving door]]. The narration states that as [[Governor of Massachusetts|governor]] of [[Massachusetts]], Dukakis vetoed [[Mandatory sentencing|mandatory minimum]] sentencing for [[drug dealers]], that he vetoed the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]], and that he gave weekend [[furlough]]s to first-degree murderers. The narrator goes on to point out that while furloughed, many of the convicts committed crimes including [[kidnapping]] and [[rape]], and are still at large. The ad concludes with the phrase: "Now Michael Dukakis says he wants to do for America what he's done for Massachusetts. America can't afford that risk." The disclaimer at the end indicates the ad was paid for and endorsed by the [[George H. W. Bush|Bush]]/[[Dan Quayle|Quayle]] campaign. ==Impact== A [[CBS News]]/[[New York Times]] poll showed that of all of the political ads of the 1988 presidential campaign, this one had the greatest impact on respondents. The percentage of poll respondents who felt Bush was "tough enough" on crime rose from 23 percent in July 1988 to 61 percent in late October 1988 while the proportion saying Dukakis was "not tough enough" on crime rose from 36 to 49 percent during the same period.{{cite web | author=InsidePolitics | title=Candidate Ads: 1988 George Bush "Revolving Door"| url=http://www.insidepolitics.org/ps111/candidateads.html | accessdate=2006-10-29}} Women particularly were affected by the ad. Said Dukakis campaign manager [[Susan Estrich]], "The symbolism was very powerful...you can't find a stronger metaphor, intended or not, for racial hatred in this country than a black man raping a white woman....I talked to people afterward....Women said they couldn't help it, but it scared the living daylights out of them." ==Furlough program== The original State inmate furlough program, for which convicted first-degree murderers were ineligible, was actually signed into law by Republican Governor [[Francis W. Sargent]] in 1972. After the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled that this right extended to first-degree murderers, the Massachusetts legislature quickly passed a bill prohibiting furloughs for such inmates. However, in 1976, Dukakis [[veto]]ed this bill. The program remained in effect through the intervening term of governor [[Edward J. King]] and was abolished during Dukakis' final term of office on April 28, 1988. This abolition only occurred after the ''[[The Eagle-Tribune|Lawrence Eagle Tribune]]'' had run 175 stories about the furlough program and won a [[Pulitzer Prize]].{{cite web |url=http://backissues.cjrarchives.org/year/95/2/pulitzers.asp |title=So What?|website=Columbia Journalism Review|year=1995|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123173623/http://backissues.cjrarchives.org/year/95/2/pulitzers.asp|archivedate=2008-01-23}} Dukakis continued to argue that the program was 99 percent effective; yet, as the ''Lawrence Eagle Tribune'' pointed out, no state outside of Massachusetts, nor any federal program, would grant a furlough to a prisoner serving life without parole. ==Related ads== ===2014 Gubernatorial Election in Illinois=== In the [[Illinois gubernatorial election, 2014|2014 Illinois governors' race]], Republican gubernatorial candidate (and eventual governor) [[Bruce Rauner]] created an attack ad entitled "Unthinkable," alleging that then-governor [[Pat Quinn (politician)|Pat Quinn]] "secretly" released 230+ violent offenders early, such as wife-beaters, rapists, sex offenders, and murderers. The ad went on to say that the consequences were "unthinkable": sexual assault of a minor, aggravated assaults, domestic abuse, and more murders. The video ends with the voiceover saying "Now Pat Quinn Wants Four More Years?".{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhNq_1Y-sWM |title=Bruce Rauner: Unthinkable}} ==References== {{portal|1980s}}
==External links== * [http://www.insidepolitics.org/ps111/candidateads.html Review at InsidePolitics.org] * [http://www.livingroomcandidate.org/commercials/1988/revolving-door Commercial viewable at Living Room Candidate] [[Category:United States presidential election, 1988]] [[Category:Political campaign advertisements]] [[Category:Television commercials]] [[Category:1980s television commercials]] [[Category:Crime in the United States]]

[[File:Vladimir Putin 24 June 2000-7.jpg|thumb|[[Vladimir Putin]] in Sabantuy, Kazan, 2000]] '''Sabantuy''' is a [[Bashkirs|Bashkir]], [[Idel-Ural]]ian and [[Tatars|Tatar]] summer [[festival]], that dates back to the [[Volga Bulgaria]]n epoch. At first Sabantuy was a festival of [[farmer]]s in rural areas, but it later became a [[Public holiday|national holiday]] and now is widely celebrated in the [[city|cities]]. In 2012, [[Kazan]] Sabantuy was celebrated on June 23.<ref>{{cite web|last=Drayton|first=James|title=Sabantuy|url=http://hometoroam.blogspot.co.uk/2012/07/sabantuy.html|work=home to roam|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref>
== Nomenclature == [[Tatar language|Tatar]]-speakers call the holiday ''Sabantuy'' (Сабантуй, {{IPA-tt|sʌbɑnˈtuɪ|}}), or, more correctly, '''Saban tuyı''' (Сабан туе, {{IPA|[sʌˈbɑn tuˈjɯ]}}) - plural form: ''Sabantuylar'' {{IPA|[sʌbɑntuɪˈlɑr]}}.
Other [[Turkic peoples]] living along the [[Volga]] also celebrate the holiday. [[Bashkir language|Bashkir]]-speakers call it '''Habantuy''' (Һабантуй), [[Chuvash language|Chuvash]]-speakers — '''Akatuy''' (Акатуй).
The [[holiday]]'s name means "[[plough]]'s [[Festival|feast]]" in [[Turkic languages]]. The synonym "plough's holiday", or '''Saban bäyräme''' (Сабан бәйрәме {{IPA|[sʌˈbɑn bæɪræˈme]}}) also occurs.
==History== Sabantuy traces its origins to the pre-[[Islam]]ic epoch, when it was celebrated before the [[sowing]] season. The presence of Sabantuy was noticed by [[ibn Fadlan]] as early as in 921. Traditional [[song]]s and other customs of the Sabantuy probably had a religious connotation at that time.
Later, with the spread of [[Islam]] among [[Tatars]] and [[Bashkirs]] and [[Christianity]] among [[Chuvash people|Chuvashs]], it became a [[secular holiday]]. In each region, [[village]]s took turns to celebrate the holiday.
In the beginning of the 20th century Sabantuy gained recognition as the national festival of the Tatars. The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] authorities approved of this festival probably due to its humble rural origin. However, they moved Sabantuy to the after-sowing season, thus merging it with the ancient summer festival ''[[Cıyın]]'' (Cyrillic: Җыен, {{IPA|[ʑɯɪˈɯn]}}).
Recently, Moscow announced plans to nominate Sabantuy for the inclusion into the [[Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity]] list in 2007.
==Traditions== The main distinctive elements of Sabantuy include the traditional sporting competitions such as ''[[köräş]]'' (Tatar wrestling), horse racing, race-in-sack, pillar-climbing, egg-in-spoon-in-mouth-racing, sacks-battle on the crossbar, pot smashing [http://www.ogoniok.com/common/archive/1996/4459/28-10-11/28-11-1b.gif], finding a coin in a ''qatıq'' (a beverage made from sour milk), and other contests. Such activities take place on the ''[[:wikt:mäydan|mäydan]]'',<ref>Мәйдан; {{IPA|[mæɪˈdɑn]}}; also ''maydan'', майдан, {{IPA|[mʌɪˈdɑn]}} in spoken language</ref> which would usually be located at the edge of a forest.
A tradition, called ''sörän'',<ref>Сөрән; {{IPA|[sœˈræn]}}</ref> was held to collect a fare for guests of the festival and prizes for the winners of the contests. ''Qarğa botqası'' (Rook's porridge),<ref>Карга боткасы, {{IPA|[qʌrˈɣɑ bɔtqɑˈsɯ]}}</ref> a ritual porridge, was cooked before the Sabantuy to treat children in the village. Another tradition was praying at the cemetery.
In the recent years Sabantuy is also often combined with the [[Music of Tatarstan|folk and pop music festivals]], as well as accordion music festivals, named ''Play, accordion!'' (''Uyna, ğarmun!'').
===[[Kurash]]=== [[File:Көрәш.JPG|thumb|Kurash ([[Tatar language|Tatar:]]Көрәш) on a Sabantuy in [[Ulyanovsk]]]] The [[wrestling]] [[Kurash]], is the main competition of Sabantuy. Wrestlers use [[towel]]s and the aim is to knock down the opponent.
Usually young boys start the competition. At the end of Sabantuy, the main event of the festival is the final of köräş. The winner becomes the ''[[batır]],''<ref>{{IPA|[bʌˈtɯr]}}, also батыр ''batyr,'' паттӑр ''pattăr''</ref> the hero of the Sabantuy. The prize varies from a [[Sheep|ram]] in small villages to a [[car]] at big cities' celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|last=Drayton|first=James|title=Sabantuy|url=http://hometoroam.blogspot.co.uk/2012/07/sabantuy.html|work=home to roam|accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref>
===Calendar of the festival=== Sabantuylar do not have a set date. The festivities take place approximately from June 15 to July 1, and usually fall on a Sunday. Initially, Sabantuylar are arranged in villages, followed by Sabantuylar in rural districts, and the final ones taking place in major cities. The last Sabantuy is held in [[Kazan]], the capital of [[Tatarstan]]. A similar schedule is applied for Akatuy in [[Chuvashia Republic|Chuvashia]] and Habantuy in [[Bashkortostan]].
In the last few years the Russian government arranged [[Russian Federation|federal]] Sabantuylar in Moscow. Many cities in [[Europe]] and [[Asia]] that have major Tatar diasporas, such as [[Moscow]], [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Tallinn]], [[Prague]], [[Istanbul]], [[Kiev]] and [[Tashkent]], also hold Sabantuylar.
Today Sabantuy can be characterized as an international festival attracting many people of various ethnicities who participate in Sabanuylar, both in Tatarstan, and all over the world.
==Political traditions== Sabantuy is a symbol of [[Tatarstan]]. This is why every Russian president visiting the republic takes part in the Sabantuy held in Kazan. During his visit to Kazan in the mid-1990s [[Boris Yeltsin]] became the center of attention at a Sabantuy when he took part in a traditional competition in which the participants try to crash a clay pot while being blindfolded. [[Vladimir Putin]] took part in a humorous competition during which he tried to dip his face into a jar full of [[Soured milk|sour milk]] in order to fish out a coin without using his hands.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://2001.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2001/41n/n41n-s07.shtml]</ref>

{{About|the belief system and practices|the organization|Church of Scientology|other uses|Scientology (disambiguation)}} {{Distinguish|Religious Science|Christian Science|Scientism}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox Organization | image = Scientology Symbol Logo.png | size = 120px | caption = The Scientology symbol is composed of the letter S, which stands for Scientology, and the [[Scientology beliefs and practices#ARC and KRC triangles|ARC and KRC triangles]], two important concepts in Scientology.{{harvnb|Cusack|2009|p=400}} | name = Scientology | formation = May 1952 | type = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Gold Base]]
[[Riverside County, California]]{{cite news | last =[[Associated Press]] | title =Rural studio is Scientology headquarters | work =[[San Jose Mercury News]] | page =6B | date =August 13, 1991 }} | leader_title = [[Chairman]] of [[Religious Technology Center]] | leader_name = [[David Miscavige]] | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = [http://www.scientology.org/ www.scientology.org] | remarks = Flagship facility: Church of Scientology International, Los Angeles, California, U.S. }} '''Scientology''' is a [[Scientology beliefs and practices|body of religious beliefs and practices]] launched in May 1952 by American author [[L. Ron Hubbard]] (1911–86). Hubbard initially developed a program of ideas called [[Dianetics]], which was distributed through the Dianetics Foundation. The foundation soon entered bankruptcy, and Hubbard lost the rights to his seminal publication ''[[Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health]]'' in 1952. He then recharacterized the subject as a religion and renamed it Scientology,{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/03/13/l-ron-hubbards-birthday-who-was-he-and-what-is-scientology-5747353/|publisher=metro.co.uk|title=L Ron Hubbard's Birthday: Who was he and what is Scientology? | Metro News|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} retaining the terminology, doctrines, the [[E-meter]], and the practice of [[Auditing (Scientology)|auditing]].{{cite web |url=http://www.smi.org/features/glossary/ |title=Scientology glossary |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}{{harvnb|Melton|2000|pp=28}} Within a year, he regained the rights to Dianetics and retained both subjects under the umbrella of the [[Church of Scientology]].{{cite book |author=Melton, J. Gordon |ref=harv | title=Encyclopedic Handbook of Cults in America |publisher=Garland Pub |location=New York |year=1992 |page=190 |isbn=978-0-8153-1140-9}}{{cite book |author=Guiley, Rosemary |title=Harper's Encyclopedia of Mystical & Paranormal Experience|publisher=HarperSanFrancisco |location=[San Francisco] |year=1991 |page=107 |isbn=978-0-06-250365-7}}{{harvnb|DeChant|Jorgenson|2003|p=227}}{{cite journal|last=Kent|first=Stephen A.|author-link =Stephen A. Kent|title=Scientology – Is this a Religion?|journal=Marburg Journal of Religion|date=July 1999|volume=4|issue=1|pages=1–23|url=http://www.uni-marburg.de/fb03/ivk/mjr/pdfs/1999/articles/kent1999.pdf|accessdate=March 3, 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zAHQbeV2?url=http://www.uni-marburg.de/fb03/ivk/mjr/pdfs/1999/articles/kent1999.pdf|archivedate=June 3, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=David|date=October 23, 2006|title=Tom's aliens target City's 'planetary rulers'|url=http://cosmedia.freewinds.be/media/articles/es231006.html|accessdate=March 3, 2013|quote=As Miscavige begins to crescendo "our next step is eradicating psychiatry from this planet, we will triumph!"|work=Evening Standard|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603210308/http://cosmedia.freewinds.be/media/articles/es231006.html|archivedate=June 3, 2013}} Hubbard describes the etymology of the word Scientology as coming from the Latin word "scio", meaning know or distinguish, and the Greek word "logos", meaning "the word or outward form by which the inward thought is expressed and made known". Hubbard writes, "thus, Scientology means knowing about knowing, or science of knowledge".{{cite journal |title=Rethinking Scientology A Thorough Analysis of L. Ron Hubbard's Formulation of Therapy and Religion in Dianetics and Scientology, 1950–1986 |journal=Alternative Spirituality and Religion Review |volume=7 |pages=155–227 |date=June 24, 2016 |last=Christensen |first=Dorthe Refslund |doi=10.5840/asrr201662323 }} Hubbard's groups have encountered considerable opposition and controversy.{{cite book |last=Reitman |first1=Janet |title=Inside Scientology: The Story of America's Most Secretive Religion |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt |year=2011 |isbn=9780547549231 }} In January 1951, the New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners brought proceedings against Dianetics Foundation on the charge of teaching medicine without a license.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=umep6P6dYLAC&pg=PA532 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160903232811/https://books.google.com/books?id=umep6P6dYLAC&pg=PA532 |archivedate=September 3, 2016 |df= |isbn=9781462712618 |last1=Lebron |first1=Robyn E |year=2012 }} Hubbard's followers engaged in a [[Operation Snow White|program of criminal infiltration]] of the [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. government]]. Hubbard-inspired organizations and their classification are often a point of contention. [[Scientology in Germany|Germany]] classifies Scientology groups as an "anti-constitutional sect".{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/hubbard-s-church-unconstitutional-germany-prepares-to-ban-scientology-a-522052.html|publisher=spiegel.de|title=Hubbard's Church 'Unconstitutional': Germany Prepares to Ban Scientology - SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=March 13, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/rap-enq/r2468.asp|publisher=assemblee-nationale.fr|title= National Assembly of France report No. 2468 |accessdate=March 13, 2017}} In [[Scientology in France|France]], they have been classified as a dangerous [[cult]] by some parliamentary reports.A 1995 [[French Parliament|parliamentary]] report lists Scientology groups as [[cult]]s, and in its 2006 report [[MIVILUDES]] similarly classified Scientology organizations as a dangerous [[cult]][http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/societe/20090525.OBS8000/le-point-sur-l-eglise-de-scientologie.html Le point sur l'Eglise de Scientologie], Le Nouvel Observateur ==History== {{See also|Timeline of Scientology|History of Dianetics}} ===L. Ron Hubbard=== {{main|L. Ron Hubbard}} {{further|Early life of L. Ron Hubbard|Military career of L. Ron Hubbard}} [[File:Hubbard and moulton.jpg|right|thumb|alt=Two men in naval uniform|L. Ron Hubbard and Thomas S. Moulton in Portland, Oregon in 1943]] [[L. Ron Hubbard]] (1911–1986) was the only child of Harry Ross Hubbard, a United States Navy officer, and his wife, Ledora Waterbury. Hubbard spent three semesters at George Washington University but was placed on probation in September 1931. He failed to return for the fall 1932 semester.Wallis, p. 21 In July 1941, Hubbard was commissioned as a Lieutenant ([[junior grade]]) in the U.S. Naval Reserve. On May 18, 1943, his [[USS PC-815|subchaser]] left Portland. That night, Hubbard ordered his crew to fire 35 depth charges and a number of gun rounds at what he believed were Japanese submarines.[[#Atack|Atack]], p. 75 His ship sustained minor damage and three crew were injured. Having run out of depth charges and with the presence of a submarine still unconfirmed by other ships, Hubbard's ship was ordered back to port. A navy report concluded that "there was no submarine in the area." A decade later, Hubbard claimed in his Scientology lectures that he had sunk a Japanese submarine.{{cite book|last=Hubbard | first=L. Ron | title=CRA Triangle | date= October 23, 1956 | series = Fifteenth American Advanced Clinical Lectures | publisher=Golden Era Publications|location=Los Angeles, CA}} On June 28, 1943, Hubbard ordered his crew to fire on the [[Coronado Islands]]. Hubbard apparently did not realize that the islands belonged to US-allied [[Mexico]], nor that he had taken his vessel into Mexican territorial waters.[[#Miller|Miller]], p. 139 He was reprimanded and removed from command on July 7. After reassignment to a naval facility in Monterey, California, Hubbard became depressed and fell ill. Reporting stomach pains in April 1945, he spent the remainder of the war as a patient in [[Oak Knoll Naval Hospital]] in Oakland, California.[[#Atack|Atack]], p. 82 According to his later teachings, during this time Hubbard made scientific "breakthroughs" by use of "endocrine experiments".{{cite web|url=http://www.wiseoldgoat.com/papers-scientology/popup-windows/scn_summary_scn_for_scientists_69.html|publisher=wiseoldgoat.com|title=A Summary on Scientology for Scientists (1969)|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} On October 15, 1947, Hubbard wrote a letter to the Veterans Administration formally requesting psychiatric treatment, but admitted that he was unable to afford it.{{cite book|title=Bare-Faced Messiah: The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|author=Miller, R.|date=2016|publisher=Silvertail Books|isbn=9781909269361|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tz0LjwEACAAJ|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} Within a few years, Hubbard would condemn psychiatry as evil, which would grow into a major theme in Scientology. ===''Excalibur'' and Babalon Working=== {{main|Scientology and the occult}} In April 1938, Hubbard reportedly reacted to a drug used in a dental procedure. According to his account, this triggered a revelatory [[near-death experience]]. Allegedly inspired by this experience, Hubbard composed a manuscript, which was never published, with the working titles of "The One Command" or ''[[Excalibur (L. Ron Hubbard)|Excalibur]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/01/24/170010096/going-clear-a-new-book-delves-into-scientology|publisher=npr.org|title='Going Clear': A New Book Delves Into Scientology: NPR|accessdate=March 13, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lermanet.com/excalibur/|publisher=lermanet.com|title=The History of Excalibur|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} The contents of ''Excalibur'' formed the basis for some of his later publications.Hubbard, "The Anatomy Of Thought". Hubbard Communication Office Policy Letter 26 April 1970R, revised March 15, 1975. [[Arthur J. Burks]], who read the work in 1938, later recalled it discussed the "one command": to survive. This theme would be revisited in Dianetics, the set of ideas and practices regarding the [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] relationship between the mind and body which became the central philosophy of Scientology.{{cite web|url=http://www.american-buddha.com/cult.yesbookcalledexcalibur.htm|publisher=american-buddha.com|title=PunʞLawyer |accessdate=March 13, 2017}} Hubbard later cited ''Excalibur'' as an early version of Dianetics.Letter to Forrest Ackerman January 13, 1949, "THE SCIENCE OF MIND, really EXCALIBUR" quoted by http://tonyortega.org/2014/10/23/l-ron-hubbard-explains-to-a-friend-the-real-reason-he-wrote-dianetics/{{better source|date=November 2015}} In August 1945, Hubbard moved into the [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] mansion of [[Jack Parsons (rocket propulsion engineer)|John "Jack" Whiteside Parsons]], an avid [[occultism|occultist]] and [[Thelema|Thelemite]], follower of the English ceremonial magician [[Aleister Crowley]] and leader of a lodge of Crowley's [[magical order]], [[Ordo Templi Orientis]] (OTO).{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Going_Clear.html|title=Google Books|website=books.google.com}}Miller, p. 113 Parsons and Hubbard collaborated on the "[[Babalon Working]]", a [[sex magic]] ritual intended to summon an incarnation of [[Babalon]], the supreme Thelemite Goddess.Urban, Hugh B. ''Magia sexualis: sex, magic, and liberation in modern Western esotericism'', p. 137. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press, 2006. {{ISBN|978-0-520-24776-5}} The Church of Scientology admits to Hubbard's involvement with Parsons while claiming that it was for the purpose of naval intelligence.{{cite book |last=Wright |first1=Lawrence |title=Going Clear: Scientology, Hollywood and the Prison of Belief |publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group |year=2013 |isbn=9780385350273 }} In the late 1940s, Hubbard practiced as a hypnotist{{cite episode| title=L. Ron Hubbard| series=Secret Lives| credits=Robinson, Jill| network=A&E|airdate=1997-11-11}} and he worked in Hollywood posing as a [[swami]].{{cite speech| first=L. Ron|last=Hubbard| title=The Story of Dianetics and Scientology, Lecture 18|date=October 1958}} The Church says that Hubbard's experience with hypnosis led him to create Dianetics.Hubbard, ''What is Scientology?'', 1998 softcover edition, pg. 529. ===Dianetics=== {{Main|Dianetics}} [[File:L. Ron Hubbard in 1950.jpg|thumb|L. Ron Hubbard in 1950]] In May 1950, Hubbard's ''[[Dianetics: The Evolution of a Science]]'' was published by pulp magazine ''[[Astounding Science Fiction]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.solitarytrees.net/pubs/skent/creation.htm?FACTNet#txtref02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312004725/http://www.solitarytrees.net/pubs/skent/creation.htm?FACTNet |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 12, 2007 |title=The Creation of 'Religious' Scientology |publisher=Religious Studies and Theology |accessdate=May 8, 2006}} Originally published by Stephen A. Kent in December 1999.{{cite book |last1=Grant |first1=Boyd |title=What is Scientology? History, Beliefs, Rules, Secrets, and Facts |date=2014|publisher=Speedy Publishing LLC|location=Newark, DE|page=4}}{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=4}}{{harvnb|Melton|2000|pp=9, 67}} In the same year, he published the book-length ''[[Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health]],'' considered the seminal event of the century by Scientologists.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|pp=9}} Scientologists sometimes use a dating system based on the book's publication; for example, "A.D. 25" does not stand for ''Anno Domini'', but "After Dianetics". Dianetics uses a counseling technique known as [[Auditing (Scientology)|auditing]] in which an auditor assists a subject in conscious recall of [[Psychological trauma|traumatic]] events in the individual's past.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=28}} It was originally intended to be a new [[psychotherapy]] and was not expected to become the foundation for a new religion.Wilson, Bryan (1970). ''Religious Sects: A Sociological Study'', McGraw-Hill, p. 163{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wpqKdDvLV0gC&pg=PA110&dq=dianetics#PPA110,M1 |title=Book: The Oxford Handbook of New Religious Movements By James R. Lewis, p. 110 |accessdate=September 4, 2010 |isbn=978-0-19-514986-9 |year=2004|last1=Lewis |first1=James R }} Hubbard variously defined Dianetics as a spiritual healing technology and an organized science of thought. The stated intent is to free individuals of the influence of past traumas by systematic exposure and removal of the [[Engram (Dianetics)|engram]]s (painful memories) these events have left behind, a process called ''clearing''.{{cite journal |title=Psychiatry and Psychology in the Writings of L. Ron Hubbard |journal=Journal of Religion and Health |date=September 2007 |volume=46 |issue=3 |pages=437–447 |doi=10.1007/s10943-006-9079-9|last1=McCall |first1=W. Vaughn }} Rutgers scholar Beryl Satter says that "there was little that was original in Hubbard's approach", with much of the theory having origins in popular conceptions of psychology. Satter observes that in "keeping with the typical 1950s distrust of emotion, Hubbard promised that Dianetic treatment would release and erase psychosomatic ills and painful emotions, thereby leaving individuals with increased powers of rationality."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ClaySHbUEogC&pg=RA4-PA189&dq=scientology+is+a+religion#v=onepage&q=psychotherapy&f=false|title=Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America: African diaspora traditions and other American innovations |last=Gallagher |last2=Ashcraft|first2=Michael|page=172|first1=Eugene|accessdate=November 5, 2015|isbn=9780275987176 |year=2006 }} According to Gallagher and Ashcraft, in contrast to psychotherapy, Hubbard stated that Dianetics "was more accessible to the average person, promised practitioners more immediate progress, and placed them in control of the therapy process." Hubbard's thought was parallel with the trend of humanist psychology at that time, which also came about in the 1950s.{{cite journal | title = The Sexual Abuse Paradigm in Historical Perspective: Passivity and Emotion in Mid-Twentieth-Century America | journal = Journal of the History of Sexuality |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/3704895?uid=3739464&uid=2&uid=3737720&uid=4&sid=21102187989543 |date = July 3, 2003 | first = Beryl | last = Satter | volume = 12 | issue = 3 | pages = 424–464 |accessdate=July 29, 2013 |doi=10.1353/sex.2004.0014}} Passas and Castillo write that the appeal of Dianetics was based on its consistency with prevailing values.Passas, Nikos, and Manuel Escamilla Castillo. "Scientology And Its 'Clear' Business." Behavioral Sciences & The Law 10.1 (1992): 103-116. Academic Search Premier Shortly after the introduction of Dianetics, Hubbard introduced the concept of the "[[thetan]]" (or soul) which he claimed to have discovered. Dianetics was organized and centralized to consolidate power under Hubbard, and groups that were previously recruited were no longer permitted to organize autonomously.{{cite journal |title=Scientology: Therapeutic Cult to Religious Sect |journal=Sociology |year=1975 |last=Wallis |first=Roy |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=89–100 |jstor=42851574 |doi=10.1177/003803857500900105}} Two of Hubbard's key supporters at the time were [[John W. Campbell Jr.]], the editor of ''Astounding Science Fiction'', and Campbell's brother-in-law, physician [[Joseph A. Winter]].{{cite book|title=Going Clear: Scientology, Hollywood, and the Prison of Belief|author=Wright, L.|date=2013|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=9780385350273|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z4IDPV2hZL0C&pg=PT85|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} Dr. Winter, hoping to have Dianetics accepted in the medical community, submitted papers outlining the principles and methodology of Dianetic therapy to the ''[[Journal of the American Medical Association]]'' and the ''[[American Journal of Psychiatry]]'' in 1949, but these were rejected.{{cite book|author=Miller, Russell|title=Bare-faced Messiah, The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|publisher=Henry Holt & Co|location=New York|edition= First American|year=1987|isbn=978-0-8050-0654-4 |page=151|url=http://www.xenu.net/archive/books/bfm/bfm09.htm}}Wallis, Roy (1977). ''[[The Road to Total Freedom: A Sociological Analysis of Scientology]]'', Columbia University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-231-04200-0}} ''Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health'' spent six months on the ''[[New York Times]]'' bestseller list.June 18, 1950 to December 24{{cite web|url=http://www.hawes.com/1950/1950.htm |title=Adult New York Times Best Seller Lists for 1950 |publisher=Hawes.com |accessdate=September 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713224538/http://www.hawes.com/1950/1950.htm |archivedate=July 13, 2012}} According to religious studies professor Paul Gutjahr, Dianetics is the bestselling non-Christian religious book of the century.{{cite journal |jstor=30227336| title = The State of the Discipline. Sacred Texts in the United States | journal = Journal Book History | volume = 4 | year = 2001 | first = Paul C. | last = Gutjahr | pages = 351–352}}{{subscription required}} Publisher's Weekly gave a posthumous plaque to Hubbard to commemorate Dianetics' appearance on its list of bestsellers for one hundred weeks. Studies that address the topic of the origins of the work and its significance to Scientology as a whole include Peter Rowley's ''New Gods in America'', Omar V. Garrison's ''The Hidden Story of Scientology'', and Albert I. Berger's ''Towards a Science of the Nuclear Mind: Science-fiction Origins of Dianetics''. More complex studies include [[Roy Wallis|Roy Wallis's]] ''The Road to Total Freedom''. Dianetics appealed to a broad range of people who used instructions from the book and applied the method to each other, becoming practitioners themselves. Dianetics soon met with criticism. [[Morris Fishbein]], the editor of the ''Journal of the American Medical Association'' and well-known at the time as a debunker of [[quack medicine]], dismissed Hubbard's book.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=13}}{{cite book |last=Lewis |first1=James R.|title=Scientology |location=USA |publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2009}} An article in Newsweek stated that "the Dianetics concept is unscientific and unworthy of discussion or review".{{cite news|title=Poor Man's Psychoanalysis?|publisher=[[Newsweek]]|date=November 6, 1950 }} Hubbard asserted that Dianetics is "an organized science of thought built on definite axioms: statements of natural laws on the order of those of the physical sciences."{{cite book |last=Carroll |first1=Robert |url=https://books.google.com/?id=6FPqDFx40vYC&dq=dianetics+science |title=The Skeptic's Dictionary: A Collection of Strange Beliefs, Amusing Deceptions, and Dangerous Delusions |accessdate=November 23, 2015|isbn=9781118045633 |date=2011-01-11 }} Hubbard became the leader of a growing Dianetics movement. He became a popular lecturer and established the Hubbard Dianetic Research Foundation in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], where he trained his first Dianetics counselors or ''auditors''.{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|p=172}} Some practitioners of Dianetics reported experiences which they believed had occurred in past lives, or previous incarnations. In early 1951, [[reincarnation]] became a subject of intense debate within the Dianetics community.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=10}} Hubbard took the reports of past life events seriously and introduced the concept of the ''[[thetan]]'', an immortal being analogous to the [[soul]]. This was an important factor in the transition from secular Dianetics to the religion of Scientology. Sociologists [[Roy Wallis]] and Steve Bruce suggest that Dianetics, which set each person as his or her own authority, was about to fail due to its inherent individualism, and that Hubbard started Scientology as a religion to establish himself as the overarching authority.{{cite journal |jstor=3711319| title = The Stark-Bainbridge Theory of Religion: A Critical Analysis and Counter Proposals | journal = Sociological Analysis | date = Spring 1984 | first = Roy | last = Wallis |author2=Steve Bruce | volume = 45 | issue = 1 | page = 24 | doi=10.2307/3711319}}Wallis, Roy. 1975. "SCIENTOLOGY: THERAPEUTIC CULT TO RELIGIOUS SECT".Sociology 9 (1). Sage Publications, Ltd.: 89–100. https://www.jstor.org/stable/42851574. Also in 1951, Hubbard incorporated the ''[[electropsychometer]]'' ([[E-meter]] for short), a kind of [[electrodermal activity]] meter, as an auditing aid. Based on a design by [[Volney Mathison]], the device is held by Scientologists to be a useful tool in detecting changes in a person's state of mind. The global spread of Scientology at the latter half of the 1950s was culminated with the opening of churches in Johannesburg and Paris, while world headquarters transferred to England in Saint Hill, a rural estate. Hubbard lived there for the next seven years.{{cite book |last=Lewis |first1=James R. |title=Scientology |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2009}} Dianetics is different from Scientology in that Scientology is a religion while Dianetics is not. The purpose of Dianetics is the improvement of the individual, the individual or "self" being only one of eight "dynamics."{{cite book |last=Chryssides |first1=George D. |last2=Wilkins |first2=Margaret |title=A Reader in New Religious Movements: Readings in the Study of New Religious Movements |publisher=Bloomsbery Academic |year=2006}} "According to Hugh B. Urban, Hubbard's early science of Dianetics would be best comprehended as a "bricolage that brought together his various explorations in psychology, hypnosis, and science fiction." If Dianetics is understood as a bricolage, then Scientology is "an even more ambitious sort of religious bricolage adapted to the new religious marketplace of 1950s America," continues Urban. According to Roy Wallis, "Scientology emerged as a religious commodity eminently suited to the contemporary market of postwar America." L. Ron Hubbard Jr. said in an interview that the spiritual bricolage of Scientology, as written by Hugh B. Urban, "seemed to be uniquely suited to the individualism and quick-fix mentality of 1950s America: just by doing a few assignments, "one can become a god." {{cite book |last=Urban |first1=Hugh B. |title=The Church of Scientology: A History of a New Religion |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=2011 |isbn=9780691146089 }} [[Harlan Ellison]] has told a story of seeing Hubbard at a gathering of the [[Hydra Club]] in 1953 or 1954. Hubbard was complaining of not being able to make a living on what he was being paid as a science fiction writer. Ellison says that [[Lester del Rey]] told Hubbard that what he needed to do to get rich was start a religion.{{cite journal |last1=Underdown |first1=James |authorlink1=James Underdown |title='I Was There...': Harlan Ellison Witnesses the Birth of Scientology |journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |date=2018 |volume=42 |issue=6 |page=10}} ===Church of Scientology=== {{Main|Church of Scientology}} [[File:The Founding Church of Scientology.jpg|thumb|upright|Founding Church of Scientology in Washington, D.C.]] In January 1951, the New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners began proceedings against the Hubbard Dianetic Research Foundation for teaching medicine without a license, which eventually led to that foundation's bankruptcy.{{harvnb|Flowers|1984|pp=96–97}}Thomas Streissguth ''Charismatic Cult Leaders'', p. 70, The Oliver Press Inc., 1996 {{ISBN|978-1-881508-18-2}}George Malko ''Scientology: the now religion'', p. 58, Delacorte Press, 1970 ASIN B0006CAHJ6 In December 1952, the Hubbard Dianetic Foundation filed for bankruptcy, and Hubbard lost control of the Dianetics trademark and copyrights to financier Don Purcell.{{cite web|url=http://tonyortega.org/2014/08/21/jon-atack-the-games-l-ron-hubbard-played/|title=Jon Atack: The games L. Ron Hubbard played|website=tonyortega.org}} Author Russell Miller argues that Scientology "was a development of undeniable expedience, since it ensured that he would be able to stay in business even if the courts eventually awarded control of Dianetics and its valuable copyrights to ... Purcell".Miller, 1987: 202-203{{cite web|url=http://www.solitarytrees.net/pubs/skent/creation.htm#dn |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050208092739/http://solitarytrees.net/pubs/skent/creation.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 8, 2005 |title=The Creation of "Religious" Scientology |website=solitarytrees.net |df= }} L. Ron Hubbard originally intended for Scientology to be considered a science, as stated in his writings. In May 1952, Scientology was organized to put this intended science into practice, and in the same year, Hubbard published a new set of teachings as ''Scientology, a religious philosophy.''Christian D. Von Dehsen-Scott L. Harris ''Philosophers and Religious Leaders'', p. 90, Greenwood Publishing Group, 1999 {{ISBN|978-1-57356-152-5}} Marco Frenschkowski quotes Hubbard in a letter written in 1953, to show that he never denied that his original approach was not a religious one: "Probably the greatest discovery of Scientology and its most forceful contribution to mankind has been the isolation, description and handling of the human spirit, accomplished in July, 1951, in Phoenix, Arizona. I established, along scientific rather than religious or humanitarian lines that the thing which is the person, the personality, is separable from the body and the mind at will and without causing bodily death or derangement. (Hubbard 1983: 55)."{{cite journal |title=Images of Religions and Religious History in the Works of L. Ron Hubbard |journal=Alternative Spirituality and Religion Review |volume=7 |pages=111–153 |year=2016 |last=Frenschkowski |first=Marco|doi=10.5840/asrr20166620 }} In April 1953, Hubbard wrote a letter proposing that Scientology should be transformed into a religion.Miller, p. 213 As membership declined and finances grew tighter, Hubbard had reversed the hostility to religion he voiced in ''Dianetics''.Kent, Stephen A. "The Creation of 'Religious' Scientology." ''Religious Studies and Theology'' '''18''':2, pp. 97–126. 1999. ISSN 1747-5414 His letter discussed the legal and financial benefits of religious status. Hubbard outlined plans for setting up a chain of "Spiritual Guidance Centers" charging customers $500 for twenty-four hours of auditing ("That is real money ... Charge enough and we'd be swamped."). He wrote: {{quote|I await your reaction on the religion angle. In my opinion, we couldn't get worse public opinion than we have had or have less customers with what we've got to sell. A religious charter would be necessary in Pennsylvania or NJ to make it stick. But I sure could make it stick.Hubbard, L. Ron. Letter of April 10, 1953. Quoted in Miller, p. 213}} In December 1953, Hubbard incorporated three churches – a "Church of American Science", a "Church of Scientology" and a "Church of Spiritual Engineering" – in [[Camden, New Jersey]].{{cite book|author=Miller, Russell|title=Bare-faced Messiah, The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|publisher=Henry Holt & Co|location=New York|edition= First American|year=1987|isbn=978-0-8050-0654-4 |pages=140–142|url=http://www.xenu.net/archive/books/bfm/bfm13.htm}} On February 18, 1954, with Hubbard's blessing, some of his followers set up the first local Church of Scientology, the Church of Scientology of California, adopting the "aims, purposes, principles and creed of the Church of American Science, as founded by L. Ron Hubbard."{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=11}} The movement spread quickly through the United States and to other English-speaking countries such as Britain, Ireland, South Africa and Australia. The second local Church of Scientology to be set up, after the one in California, was in [[Auckland, New Zealand]].{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=12}} In 1955, Hubbard established the [[L. Ron Hubbard House|Founding Church of Scientology]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]. The group declared that the Founding Church, as written in the certificate of incorporation for the Founding Church of Scientology in the District of Columbia, was to "act as a parent church for the religious faith known as 'Scientology' and to act as a church for the religious worship of the faith."{{cite book |last=Zald |first1=Mayer N. |last2=McCarthy |first2=John David |title=Social Movements in an Organizational Society: Collected Essays |publisher=Transaction Publishers |date=1987 |isbn=9780887388026 |url= {{Google books|id=dVHJAgAAQBAJ|page=78|plainurl=yes}}}}{{better source|reason= looking at p 78 of source Zald, it's clear they're quoting p 89 of a source named Stoner, so this is still not the entirely correct way to do this citation|date=February 2017}} The Church experienced further challenges. The United States [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) began an investigation concerning the claims the Church of Scientology made in connection with its E-meters. On January 4, 1963, FDA agents raided offices of the Church of Scientology, seizing hundreds of E-meters as illegal medical devices and tons of literature that they accused of making false medical claims.{{Cite book|title = The Hidden Story of Scientology|last = Garrison|first = Omar V.|publisher = Citadel Press, Lyle Suart, Inc.|year = 1974|isbn = 978-0-8065-0440-7|location = Secaucus, NJ|page=135}} The original suit by the FDA to condemn the literature and E-meters did not succeed,{{Cite book|title = The hidden Story of Scientology|last = Garrison|first = Omar V.|publisher = Citadel Press, Lyle Stuart, Inc.|year = 1974|isbn = 978-0-8065-0440-7|location = Secaucus, MJ|pages=136, 142}} but the Court ordered the Church to label every meter with a disclaimer that it is purely religious artifact,{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/E-Meter/Mark-VII/ |title=1963 FDA raid |publisher=Cs.cmu.edu |date=January 4, 1963 |accessdate=September 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019110136/http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/E-Meter/Mark-VII/ |archivedate=October 19, 2012 }} to post a $20,000 bond of compliance, and to pay the FDA's legal expenses.{{Cite book|title = The Hidden Story of Scientology|last = Garrison|first = Omar V.|publisher = Citadel Press, Lyle Stuart, Inc.|year = 1974|isbn = 978-0-8065-0440-7|location = Secaucus, NJ|page=143}} In the course of developing Scientology, Hubbard presented rapidly changing teachings that some have seen as often self-contradictory.{{cite book|last=Wallis|first=Roy|title=The Road to Total Freedom|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|year=1977|page=153}} According to Lindholm, for the inner cadre of Scientologists in that period, involvement depended not so much on belief in a particular doctrine but on unquestioning faith in Hubbard.{{cite journal|last=Lindholm|first=Charles|year=1992|title=Charisma, Crowd Psychology and Altered States of Consciousness|journal=Culture, Medicine and Psychiatry|volume=16|issue=3|pages=287–310|doi=10.1007/BF00052152|ref=harv|hdl=2144/3836}} In 1966, Hubbard purportedly stepped down as executive director of Scientology to devote himself to research and writing.{{harvnb|DeChant|Jorgenson|2003|p=225}} The following year, he formed the ship-based Sea Organization or [[Sea Org]] which operated three ships: the ''Diana'', the ''Athena'', and the flagship the ''Apollo''.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=17}} One month after the establishment of the Sea Org, Hubbard announced that he had made a breakthrough discovery, the result of which were the "[[OT III]]" materials purporting to provide a method for overcoming factors inhibiting spiritual progress. These materials were first disseminated on the ships, and then propagated by Sea Org members reassigned to staff Advanced Organizations on land. ===Hubbard in hiding, death, and aftermath=== In 1972, facing criminal charges in France, Hubbard returned to the United States and began living in an apartment in [[Queens]], New York.{{cite web|url=http://tonyortega.org/2015/02/16/the-paranoid-depressed-l-ron-hubbard-jim-dincalcis-1997-secret-lives-tv-interview/|publisher=tonyortega.org|title=The paranoid, depressed L. Ron Hubbard: Jim Dincalci's 1997 'Secret Lives' TV interview ' The Underground Bunker|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} When faced with possible indictment in the United States, Hubbard went into hiding in April 1979. He hid first in an apartment in [[Hemet, California]], where his only contact with the outside world was via ten trusted Messengers. He cut contact with everyone else, even his wife, whom he saw for the last time in August 1979.Atack, p. 258 In February 1980 he disappeared into deep cover in the company of two trusted Messengers, Pat and Anne Broeker.Atack, p. 259Miller, p. 364 In 1979, as a result of FBI raids during [[Operation Snow White]], eleven senior people in the church's Guardian's Office were convicted of obstructing justice, burglary of government offices, and theft of documents and government property. In 1981, Scientology took the German government to court for the first time.Elisabeth Amveck ''Researching New Religious Movements'', p. 261, Routledge, 2006 {{ISBN|978-0-415-27754-9}} On January 24, 1986, L. Ron Hubbard died at his ranch in [[Creston, California]].[http://www.newtimesslo.com/cover/2628/l-ron-hubbards-last-refuge/ L. Ron Hubbard's last refuge | Cover Story | New Times San Luis Obispo, CA] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217013657/http://www.newtimesslo.com/cover/2628/l-ron-hubbards-last-refuge/ |date=December 17, 2013 }} [[David Miscavige]] emerged as the new head of the organization. ===Splinter groups: Independent Scientology, Freezone, and Miscavige's RTC=== {{main|Free Zone (Scientology)}} While ''Scientology'' generally refers to [[David Miscavige|Miscavige]]-led [[Church of Scientology]], other groups practice Scientology. These groups, collectively known as Independent Scientologists, consist of former members of the official Church of Scientology as well as entirely new members. In 1950, founding member Joseph Winter cut ties with Hubbard and set up a private Dianetics practice in New York.{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Library/Shelf/wallis/wallis1.txt|publisher=cs.cmu.edu|title=~dst/Library/Shelf/wallis/wallis1|accessdate=March 13, 2017}} In 1965, a longtime Church member and "Doctor of Scientology" Jack Horner (born 1927), dissatisfied with the Church's "ethics" program, developed Dianology.{{cite book |last1=Melton|first1=J. G. (Ed.)|chapter=Church of Eductivism |title=Encyclopedia of American Religions|year=2003|publisher=Detroit: Gale|page=815}} Capt. Bill Robertson, a former Sea Org member, was a primary instigator of the movement in the early 1980s.{{cite web|author=Free Zone Assoc. |url=http://www.freezone.org/news/intro.htm |title=Introduction |publisher=Freezone.org |date=January 30, 2002 |accessdate=September 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109194238/http://www.freezone.org/news/intro.htm |archivedate=November 9, 2013 }} The church labels these groups "[[Squirreling|squirrels]]" ([[Scientology terminology|Scientology jargon]]) and often subjects them to considerable legal and social pressure.{{cite news | last = Meyer-Hauser | first = Bernard F. | title = Religious Technology Center v. Freie Zone E. V | work = Case No. D2000-0410 | publisher = | date = June 23, 2000 | url = http://www.jurawelt.com/gerichtsurteile/sonstige/ausland/5006 | accessdate = | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20130928140505/http://www.jurawelt.com/gerichtsurteile/sonstige/ausland/5006| archivedate =September 28, 2013}}{{cite news | last = Brown | first = Janelle | title = Copyright – or wrong? : The Church of Scientology takes up a new weapon – the Digital Millennium Copyright Act – in its ongoing battle with critics | work = [[Salon.com|Salon]] | language = | publisher = | date = July 22, 1999 | url = http://www.salon.com/tech/feature/1999/07/22/scientology/print.html | accessdate = | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090626222533/http://www.salon.com/tech/feature/1999/07/22/scientology/print.html| archivedate =June 26, 2009}} {{cite web|last=Colette|first=Mark|title=Former Scientology film crew member describes surveillance activities in Ingleside on the Bay|url=http://www.caller.com/news/2011/aug/06/former-scientology-film-crew-member-describes-in/|publisher=Caller-Times, Corpus Christi|accessdate=September 6, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105133404/http://www.caller.com/news/2011/aug/06/former-scientology-film-crew-member-describes-in/|archivedate=November 5, 2013}} On January 1, 1982, Miscavige established the [[Religious Technology Center]] (RTC).{{harvnb|Lewis|Hammer|2007|p=24}} On November 11, 1982, the [[Free Zone (Scientology)|Free Zone]] was established by top Scientologists in disagreement with RTC.William W. Zellner ''Extraordinary Groups'', p. 295, Macmillan, 2007 {{ISBN|978-0-7167-7034-3}} The Free Zone Association was founded and registered under the laws of Germany, and espouses the doctrine that the official Church of Scientology led by [[David Miscavige]] has departed from Hubbard's original philosophy.{{cite web|url=http://www.freezone.org/english.htm |title=Free Zone |accessdate=July 13, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409102933/http://www.freezone.org/english.htm |archivedate=April 9, 2014 }} The [[Advanced Ability Center]] was established by Hubbard's personal auditor [[David Mayo (Scientology)|David Mayo]] after February 1983 – a time when some of Scientology's upper and middle management split with [[David Miscavige|Miscavige]]'s organization.[[#Nordhausen|Nordhausen & Billerbeck (2008)]], pp. 469–470 More recently, high-profile defectors [[Mark Rathbun]] and [[Mike Rinder]] have championed the cause of Independent Scientologists wishing to practice Scientology outside of the Church.{{cite news | last = Sweeney | first = John | title = Mr Shouty and Cruise: the rematch | date = September 26, 2010 | work = The Sunday Times | url = | quote = Marty Rathbun, who like Rinder is now an independent scientologist ... Rinder, though a 'heretic' to the church, lives and breathes Independent scientology. }}{{cite news | last1 = Tobin | first1 = Thomas C. | last2 = Childs | first2= Joe | title = In new year's message, Scientology insider blasts 'extreme' fundraising | date = January 1, 2012 | work = [[Tampa Bay Times]] | url = http://www.tampabay.com/news/scientology/in-new-years-message-scientology-insider-blasts-extreme-fundraising/1208723 | quote = Rathbun, now a leading figure in a movement for Scientologists to practice independently of the church ... | accessdate = January 14, 2012 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130625183722/http://www.tampabay.com/news/scientology/in-new-years-message-scientology-insider-blasts-extreme-fundraising/1208723 | archivedate = June 25, 2013 }} ==Beliefs and practices== {{Main|Scientology beliefs and practices}} According to Scientology, its beliefs and practices are based on rigorous research, and its doctrines are accorded a significance equivalent to scientific laws.{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|pp=170–171}} Scientology cosmology is, however, at odds with modern science, with claims of memories going back "76 trillion years":{{cite book|last1=Hubbard|first1=L. Ron|title=Scientology : the fundamentals of thought|date=2007|publisher=Bridge Publications|location=Commerce, Calif.|isbn=9781403144201|page=178|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aqxDAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA178|accessdate=December 21, 2015}} much longer than the [[age of the universe]]. Blind belief is held to be of lesser significance than the practical application of Scientologist methods. Adherents are encouraged to validate the practices through their personal experience. Hubbard put it this way: "For a Scientologist, the final test of any knowledge he has gained is, 'did the data and the use of it in life actually improve conditions or didn't it?{{Single double}} He defined Scientology's aims as: "A civilization without insanity, without criminals and without war; where the world can prosper and honest beings can have rights, and where man is free to rise to greater heights, are the aims of Scientology."{{cite book |last=Wilkins |first1=Margaret |last2=Chryssides |first2=George D. |title=A Reader in New Religious Movements: Readings in the Study of New Religious Movements |publisher=A&C Black |year=2006 }}{{cite book |last=Kent |first1=Stephen A. |title=From Slogans to Mantras: Social Protest and Religious Conversion in the Late Vietnam War Era |publisher=Syracuse University Pres |year=2001 }} He described Scientology as an "applied religious philosophy" because, according to him, it consists of a metaphysical doctrine, a theory of psychology, and teachings in morality.{{cite conference |last=Dericquebourg |first=Regis |title=Acta Comparanda |language=English, French |url=http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |booktitle=Affinities between Scientology and Theosophy |conference=International Conference – Scientology in a scholarly perspective 24-25th January 2014 |publisher=University of Antwerp, Faculty for Comparative Study of Religions and Humanism |place=Antwerp, Belgium |year=2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216050903/http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |archivedate=February 16, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} The core of Scientology teaching lies in the belief that "each human has a reactive mind that responds to life's traumas, clouding the analytic mind and keeping us from experiencing reality." Scientologists undergo auditing to discover sources of this trauma, believing that re-experiencing it neutralizes it and reinforces the ascendancy of the analytic mind, with the final goal believed to be achieving a spiritual state that Scientology calls "clear." === Theological doctrine === Scientology does not preach or impose a particular idea of God on Scientologists. Rather, people are expected to discover the truth through their own observations as their awareness advances.
... the Church of Scientology has no set dogma concerning God that it imposes on its members. As with all its tenets, Scientology does not ask individuals to accept anything on faith alone. Rather, as one's level of spiritual awareness increases through participation in Scientology ''auditing'' and ''training'', one attains his own certainty of every dynamic. Accordingly, only when the Seventh Dynamic (spiritual) is reached in its entirety will one discover and come to a full understanding of the Eighth Dynamic (infinity) and one's relationship to the Supreme Being.{{cite web|title = Does Scientology have a concept of God?|url = http://www.scientology.org/faq/scientology-beliefs/what-is-the-concept-of-god-in-scientology.html|website = www.scientology.org|accessdate = December 31, 2015|language = en-US}}
Many Scientologists avoid using the words "belief" or "faith" to describe how Hubbard's teachings impacts their lives. They perceive that Scientology is based on verifiable technologies, speaking to Hubbard's original scientific objectives for Dianetics, based on the quantifiability of auditing on the E-meter. Scientologists call Dianetics and Scientology as technologies because of their claim of their scientific precision and workability.{{cite book |last=Lewis |first1=J. |title=Handbook of Scientology |volume=Brill Handbooks on Contemporary Religion |editor-last=Lewis |editor-first=James R. |editor2-last=Hellesoy |editor2-first=Kjersti |publisher=Brill |year=2017 |isbn=9789004330542 }} ===Reactive mind, traumatic memories, and auditing=== {{See also|Dianetics|Auditing (Scientology)}} [[File:Stresstest.jpg|thumb|A Scientologist introduces the [[E-meter]] to a potential student]] Scientology presents two major divisions of the mind.{{harvnb|Flowers|1984|p=98}} The ''[[reactive mind]]'' is thought to record all pain and emotional trauma, while the ''analytical mind'' is a rational mechanism that serves consciousness.{{cite book |author=Bednarowski, Mary Farrell |title=New Religions and the Theological Imagination in America (Religion in North America) |publisher=Indiana University Press |location=Bloomington |year=1995 |page=60 |isbn=978-0-253-20952-8}} The reactive mind stores mental images which are not readily available to the analytical (conscious) mind; these are referred to as ''[[Engram (Dianetics)|engrams]]''.{{cite book |author=Pollock, Robert |title=The Everything World's Religions Book: Discover the Beliefs, Traditions, and Cultures of Ancient and Modern Religions |publisher=Adams Media Corporation |location=Avon, MA |year=2002 |page=210 |isbn=978-1-58062-648-4}} Engrams are painful and debilitating; as they accumulate, people move further away from their true identity. To avoid this fate is Scientology's basic goal. Some engrams are taught by Hubbard to happen by accident while others are inflicted by "thetans who have gone bad and want power," as described by the Los Angeles Times. These engrams are named Implants in the doctrine of Scientology. Hubbard said, "Implants result in all varieties of illness, apathy, degradation, neurosis and insanity and are the principal cause of these in man."{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/la-scientologysidea062490-story.html|title=Defining the Theology|last=Sappell|first=Joel|last2=Welkos|first2=Robert W.|date=June 24, 1990|publisher=|accessdate=January 14, 2017|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}} L. Ron Hubbard described the analytical mind in terms of a computer: "the analytical mind is not just a good computer, it is a perfect computer." According to him it makes the best decisions based on available data. Errors are made based on erroneous data, and is not the error of the analytical mind. Dianetic [[Auditing (Scientology)|auditing]] is one way by which the Scientologist may progress toward the ''[[Clear (Scientology)|Clear]]'' state, winning gradual freedom from the reactive mind's engrams and acquiring certainty of his or her reality as a thetan. [[David V. Barrett]], a sociologist of religion who has written widely about the subject, says that according to Scientology, the "first major goal is to go Clear." Clearing was described to represent "the attainment of Man's dreams through the ages of attaining a new and higher state of existence and freedom from the endless cycle of birth, death, birth … Clear is the total erasure of the reactive mind from which stems all the anxieties and problems the individual has."{{cite book |last=Barrett |first1=David V. |authorlink=David V. Barrett |title=A Brief Guide to Secret Religions: A Complete Guide to Hermetic, Pagan and Esoteric Beliefs |publisher=Little, Brown Book Group |year=2011 }} Scientology asserts that people have hidden abilities which have not yet been fully realized.J. Gordon Melton ''The Encyclopedia of American Religion'', p. 224, McGrath Publishing Co., 1978 {{ISBN|978-0-7876-9696-2}} It teaches that increased spiritual awareness and physical benefits are accomplished through counseling sessions referred to as ''[[Auditing (Scientology)|auditing]]''.Paul Finkelman ''Religion and American Law'', p. 509, Taylor & Francis, 2000 {{ISBN|978-0-8153-0750-1}} Through auditing, people can solve their problems and free themselves of engrams. This restores them to their natural condition as thetans and enables them to be ''at cause'' in their daily lives, responding rationally and creatively to life events rather than reacting to them under the direction of stored engrams.{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|p=175}} Accordingly, those who study Scientology materials and receive auditing sessions advance from a status of ''Preclear'' to ''Clear'' and ''Operating Thetan''.{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|pp=176–177}} Scientology's utopian aim is to "clear the planet", that is, clear all people in the world of their engrams.{{harvnb|Palmer|2009|p=316}} Auditing is a one-on-one session with a Scientology counselor or ''auditor.''{{harvnb|DeChant|Jorgenson|2003|pp=229–230}} It is similar to [[Confession (religion)|confession]] or pastoral counseling, but the auditor records and stores all information received and does not dispense forgiveness or advice as a pastor or priest of another religion might do. Instead, the auditor's task is to help a person discover and understand the universal principles of [[ARC triangle|affinity, reality, and communication]] (ARC). Most auditing requires an [[E-meter]], a device that measures minute changes in [[electrical resistance]] through the body when a person holds electrodes (metal "cans"), and a small current is passed through them. Scientology teaches that the E-meter helps to locate spiritual difficulties. Once an area of concern has been identified, the auditor asks the individual specific questions about it to help him or her eliminate the difficulty, and uses the E-meter to confirm that the "charge" has been dissipated. As the individual progresses up the "Bridge to Total Freedom", the focus of auditing moves from simple engrams to engrams of increasing complexity and other difficulties. At the more advanced OT levels, Scientologists act as their own auditors ("solo auditors"). Douglas E. Cowan writes that the e-meter "provides an external, material locus for the legitimation of [Scientology] practice." Scientologists depend on the "appearance of objectivity or empirical validity" of the e-meter rather than simply trusting an auditor's abstract interpretation of a participant's statements. He also states that without the e-meter, "Scientology could not have achieved whatever status it enjoys as a new religious movement." He also argues that without it, the Church may not have survived the early years when Dianetics was just formed.{{cite conference |last=Cowan |first=Douglas E. |title=Acta Comparanda |language=English, French |url=http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |booktitle=Clearly Material: Objects, Meaning, and the Ongoing Construction of New Religious Reality. |conference=International Conference – Scientology in a scholarly perspective 24-25th January 2014 |publisher=University of Antwerp, Faculty for Comparative Study of Religions and Humanism |place=Antwerp, Belgium |year=2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216050903/http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |archivedate=February 16, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} ===Emotional Tone Scale and survival=== {{main|Emotional tone scale|Science of Survival}} Scientology uses an emotional classification system called the ''[[Emotional tone scale|tone scale]]''.{{cite book |author=Malko, George |title=Scientology: The Now Religion |publisher=Delacorte Press |location=New York |year=1970 |page=109 |isbn=978-1-112-96373-5}} The tone scale is a tool used in auditing; Scientologists maintain that knowing a person's place on the scale makes it easier to predict his or her actions and assists in bettering his or her condition.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kkj3yBwED2IC&pg=PA132&dq=Scientology+tone+scale |title=The Oxford Handbook of Religion and Emotion, page 132 |author=John Corrigan |isbn=978-0-19-517021-4 |year=2008}} Scientology emphasizes the importance of ''survival'', which it subdivides into eight classifications that are referred to as ''"[[Scientology beliefs and practices#The Dynamics|dynamics]]"''.{{cite web | url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Library/Shelf/wallis/wallis1.txt |title=The Road to Total Freedom A Sociological analysis of Scientology, page 1 |author=Roy Wallis |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015230830/http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Library/Shelf/wallis/wallis1.txt |archivedate=October 15, 2013 }}{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=31}} An individual's desire to survive is considered to be the first dynamic, while the second dynamic relates to procreation and family.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=25}} The remaining dynamics encompass wider fields of action, involving groups, mankind, all life, the physical universe, the spirit, and infinity, often associated with the Supreme Being. The optimum solution to any problem is held to be the one that brings the greatest benefit to the greatest number of dynamics. ===Toxins and purification=== {{main|Purification Rundown}} The Purification Rundown{{cite book|title=Australian Soul: Religion and Spirituality in the 21st Century |first=Gary D. |last=Bouma|publisher=Cambridge University Press| year=2006|page=9|isbn=978-0-521-67389-1}} is a controversial "detoxification" program used by the [[Church of Scientology]] as an introductory service.{{cite book|last=Christensen|first=Dorthe Refslund|title=Scientology|editor=James R. Lewis|publisher=Oxford University Press US|location=New York|year=2009|pages=420–421|chapter=Sources for the Study of Scientology|isbn=978-0-19-533149-3}} It features high-dose dietary supplements and extended time in a sauna (up to five hours a day for five weeks).{{cite journal| last=Al-Zaki |first=Taleb|author2=B Tilman Jolly |date=January 1997| title=Severe Hyponatremia After Purification |journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine |doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(97)70335-4 |volume=29 |issue=1 | pages=194–195| pmid=8998113}} Scientology claims it is the only effective way to deal with the long-term effects of drug abuse or toxic exposure.
