Morgan|date=March 29, 1999|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|quote=In the United States, Scientology gained ''status as a tax-exempt religion'' in 1993 when the Internal Revenue Service agreed to end a long legal battle over the group's right to the exemption.}}Toomey, Shamus (June 26, 2005). [https://web.archive.org/web/20050629002146/http://www.suntimes.com/output/news/cst-nws-scientology26.html "'TomKat' casts spotlight back on Scientology."], ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]] The organization is considered a cult in [[Chile]] and an "anticonstitutional sect" in Germany, and is considered a cult (French ''secte'') by some French public authorities. The church argues that Scientology is a genuine religious movement that has been misrepresented, maligned, and persecuted.{{cite book | last1 = Urban | first1 = Hugh B. | title = The Church of Scientology: A History of a New Religion |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/02/church-of-scientology-urban-review |page = 2 |publisher = Princeton Press |isbn=978-0-691-14608-9 |deadurl=no |accessdate=July 29, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716014040/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/sep/02/church-of-scientology-urban-review |archivedate=July 16, 2012 | date = 2011-08-22 }}{{harvnb|Willms|2009|p=245}}. "''Being a religion'' is one of the most important issues of Scientology's current self-representation." The Church of Scientology has pursued an extensive [[public relations]] campaign for the recognition of Scientology as a tax-exempt religion in the various countries in which it exists.{{cite news | first = Dominic | last = Kennedy | title = 'Church' that yearns for respectability | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article1975105.ece | work = The Times | date = June 23, 2007 | accessdate = January 4, 2009|quote=Scientology is probably unique in that it keeps its sacred texts secret until, typically, devotees have paid enough money to learn what they say. | location=London | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110523203832/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/faith/article1975105.ece | archivedate = May 23, 2011 }}{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2007|p=17}}{{cite news | first = Wayne | last = Garcia | title = Scientology suit on PR firm heads for trial | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/51826396.html?dids=51826396:51826396&FMT=FT | work = St. Petersburg Times | date = March 31, 1994 | accessdate = January 4, 2009 |quote=For 2{{frac|1|2 }} years, Hill & Knowlton worked closely with the controversial religion, coming up with ways to turn around Scientology's maligned image and teaching Scientologists how to handle reporters' questions.}} Scientology has often encountered opposition due to its strong-arm tactics directed against critics and members wishing to leave the organization. A number of governments regard the Church as a religious organization entitled to tax-exempt status, while governments variously classify it as a business, cult, [[pseudoreligion]], or criminal organization.{{cite journal|first=Douglas E.|last=Cowan|title=Researching Scientology: Academic Premises, Promises, and Problematic|publisher=CESNUR 2004 International Conference|date=July 2004|url=http://www.cesnur.org/2004/waco_cowan.htm|accessdate=June 23, 2006}}{{cite journal|author=Hexham, Irving|title=The Religious Status of Scientology: Is Scientology a Religion?|publisher=University of Calgary|origyear=1978|year=1997|url=https://www.ucalgary.ca/~nurelweb/papers/irving/scient.html|accessdate=June 13, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091119050104/http://www.ucalgary.ca/~nurelweb/papers/irving/scient.html|archivedate=November 19, 2009}} In 1957, the Church of Scientology of California was granted tax-exempt status by the United States [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS), and so, for a time, were other local churches.{{cite news|first=Douglas|last=Frantz|title=Scientology's Puzzling Journey From Tax Rebel to Tax Exempt|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B05E7DE1639F93AA35750C0A961958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all|work=New York Times|date=March 9, 1997|accessdate=October 26, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321061944/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B05E7DE1639F93AA35750C0A961958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all|archivedate=March 21, 2008}} In 1958 however, the IRS started a review of the appropriateness of this status. In 1959, Hubbard moved to England, remaining there until the mid-1960s. In the mid-sixties, the Church of Scientology was banned in several Australian states, starting with [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] in 1965.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=14}} The ban was based on the [[Anderson Report]], which found that the auditing process involved "command" hypnosis, in which the hypnotist assumes "positive authoritative control" over the patient. On this point the report stated,
It is the firm conclusion of this Board that most scientology and dianetic techniques are those of authoritative hypnosis and as such are dangerous ... the scientific evidence which the Board heard from several expert witnesses of the highest repute ... leads to the inescapable conclusion that it is only in name that there is any difference between authoritative hypnosis and most of the techniques of scientology. Many scientology techniques are in fact hypnotic techniques, and Hubbard has not changed their nature by changing their names.{{cite book|last1=Anderson|first1=Kevin Victor, Q.C.|author-link=Kevin Victor Anderson|others=Victoria Board of Enquiry into Scientology|title=Report of the Board of Enquiry into Scientology|publisher=Government Printer|location=Melbourne|year=1965|page=155}}
The Australian Church was forced to operate under the name of the "[[Church of the New Faith]]" as a result, the name and practice of Scientology having become illegal in the relevant states. Several years of court proceedings aimed at overturning the ban followed. In 1973, state laws banning Scientology were overturned in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia. In 1983 the High Court of Australia ruled in a unanimous decision that the Church of Scientology was "undoubtedly a religion and deserving of tax exemption.".{{cite book |last=Lewis |first1=James R. |url=https://books.google.com/?id=MtW90YkkB3gC&dq=anderson+report+repealed+scientology|title=Scientology |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=November 23, 2015 |isbn=9780199715954 |date=2009-03-11 }} In 1967, the IRS removed Scientology's tax-exempt status, asserting that its activities were commercial and operated for the benefit of Hubbard, rather than for charitable or religious purposes. The decision resulted in a process of litigation that was settled in the Church's favor a quarter of a century later, the longest case of litigation in IRS history. ===Scientology as a religion=== Scientology is officially recognized as a religion in the United States.{{cite conference|first=Derek H.|last=Davis|title=The Church of Scientology: In Pursuit of Legal Recognition|booktitle=Zeitdiagnosen: Religion and Conformity|publisher=Lit Verlag|year=2004|location=Münster, Germany|url=http://www.umhb.edu/files/academics/crl/publications/articles/the_church_of_scientologypursuit_of_legal_recognition.pdf|accessdate=May 10, 2008|format=PDF|quote=Many countries, including the United States, now give ''official recognition'' to Scientology as a religion [...]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5o4YGXMBa?url=http://www.umhb.edu/files/academics/crl/publications/articles/the_church_of_scientologypursuit_of_legal_recognition.pdf|archivedate=March 8, 2010}} Recognition came in 1993,Phillip Lucas ''New Religious Movements in the 21st Century'', p. 235, Routledge, 2004 {{ISBN|978-0-415-96577-4}} when the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) stated that "[Scientology is] operated exclusively for religious and charitable purposes.""Recognition was based upon voluminous information provided by the Church regarding its financial and other operations to the Internal Revenue Service." IRS press release December 31, 1997 {{cite web |url=http://www.unclefed.com/Tax-News/1997/Nr97-50.html |title=Church of Scientology & IRS Confidentiality |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518034238/http://www.unclefed.com/Tax-News/1997/Nr97-50.html |archivedate=May 18, 2012 }}. Retrieved August 13, 2007.{{cite news|first=David |last=Dahl |author2=Vick, Karl |title=IRS examined Scientology dollars, not dogma |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/51783695.html?dids=51783695:51783695&FMT=FT&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Oct+24%2C+1993&author=DAVID+DAHL&pub=St.+Petersburg+Times&edition=&startpage=1.A&desc=IRS+examined+Scientology+dollars%2C+not+dogma |publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=October 24, 1993 |accessdate=August 31, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012213911/https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/51783695.html?dids=51783695%3A51783695&FMT=FT&FMTS=ABS%3AFT&date=Oct%2B24%2C%2B1993&author=DAVID%2BDAHL&pub=St.%2BPetersburg%2BTimes&edition=&startpage=1.A&desc=IRS%2Bexamined%2BScientology%2Bdollars%2C%2Bnot%2Bdogma |archivedate=October 12, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Scientology was again recognized as a religion by the U.S. courts when the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment in ''[[Headley v. Church of Scientology International]]'' in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.pe.com/articles/headleys-655156-claire-headley.html|title=CHURCH OF SCIENTOLOGY: Two former ministers' lawsuit loses on appeal|last=De ATLEY|first=RICHARD K.|date=July 24, 2012|website=Press Enterprise|publisher=Press Enterprise|accessdate=March 24, 2016}} The ''[[New York Times]]'' noted in this connection that the Church of Scientology had funded a campaign which included a whistle-blower organization to publicly attack the IRS, as well as hiring of private investigators to look into the private lives of IRS officials. In 1991, Miscavige, the highest-ranking Scientology leader, arranged a meeting with [[Fred T. Goldberg Jr.]], the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service at the time.{{cite news|first=Douglas|last=Frantz|title= Scientology Denies an Account Of an Impromptu IRS Meeting |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A04EED81038F93AA25750C0A961958260 | work=New York Times|date=March 19, 1997|accessdate=January 18, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115145812/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A04EED81038F93AA25750C0A961958260|archivedate=January 15, 2008}} The meeting was an "opportunity for the church to offer to end its long dispute with the agency, including the dozens of suits brought against the IRS." The committee met several times with the Scientology legal team and "was persuaded that those involved in the Snow White crimes had been purged, that church money was devoted to tax-exempt purposes and that, with Mr. Hubbard's death, no one was getting rich from Scientology." In August 1993, a settlement was reached; the church would receive its tax-exempt status and end its legal actions against the IRS and its personnel. The church was required only to resubmit new applications for exemption to the IRS Exempt Organizations (EO) division, which was told "not to consider any substantive matters" because those issues had been resolved by the committee. The secret agreement was announced on October 13, 1993, with the IRS refusing to disclose any of the terms or the reasoning behind the decision. Both the IRS and Scientology rejected any allegations that foul play or undue pressure had been used on IRS officials, insisting that the decision had been based on the merits of the case.{{harvnb|Richardson|2009|p=288}} IRS officials "insisted that Scientology's tactics had not affected the decision" and that "ultimately the decision was made on a legal basis". Miscavige claims that the IRS's examination of Scientology was the most exhaustive review of any non-profit organization in history.{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Fishman/Declaration/dmdec.txt |title=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Fishman/Declaration/dmdec.txt |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206171239/http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Fishman/Declaration/dmdec.txt |archivedate=February 6, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Elsewhere, Scientology is recognized as a religion in Australia,{{harvnb|Richardson|2009|p=286}}: "After doing a thorough analysis, the [High] Court [of Australia] ''stated unequivocally that Scientology met the criteria establishing itself as a religion'', and therefore should be granted exempt status for tax purposes. The Court went on to state that a religion did not have to be theistic, and that a religion involved both belief and behavior ... This case is still the leading case in Australia defining religion, and is cited in other courts and countries as well." Portugal,{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100579.htm |title=2007 U.S. State Department – 2007 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Portugal }}: "In November the government ''officially recognized Scientology as a religion''." Spain,{{cite web |url=http://www.elheraldo.com.ar/ver_noticias.php?id_nota=8175 |title=Cienciología entre las "entidades religiosas" |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130411191515/http://www.elheraldo.com.ar/ver_noticias.php?id_nota=8175 |archivedate=April 11, 2013 }}: "Un tribunal administrativo de la Audiencia Nacional de Madrid, máxima instancia judicial española, aceptó un recurso interpuesto por ese movimiento fundado en 1954 por el autor de ciencia ficción Lafayette Ron Hubbard (1911–1986), para ser inscripto en el registro de los movimientos religiosos del país." [[Slovenia]], Sweden,{{cite web|url=http://www.cesnur.org/testi/scient_sweden2000.htm|title=Decision of 13 March 2000 registering Scientology as a "religious community" in Sweden|date=March 13, 2000|accessdate=July 21, 2007|publisher=[[CESNUR]]}}{{harvnb|Bogdan|2009|p=338}}: "on March 13, 2000, the Church of Scientology was ''registered as a religious community'' by the National Judicial Board for Public Lands and Funds following a new law, titled the Act on Religious Communities ..., which took on effect on January 1, 2000, with the separation of the Church of Sweden from the state. On June 10, 2000, the first legal Scientology wedding in Europe was celebrated in Stockholm." [[Croatia]], [[Hungary]]{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&objet_id=1019433 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120804122800/http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&objet_id=1019433 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-04 |title=La justice espagnole accorde à la Scientologie le statut de religion }}, 2008-01-09, ''[[Le Monde]]'' and [[Kyrgyzstan]].{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51562.htm |title=U.S. State Department – 2005 Report on International Religious Freedom: Kyrgyzstan }}: "In the past year the State Commission on Religious Affairs (SCRA) also registered the Church of Scientology" In New Zealand, the Inland Revenue Department classified the Church of Scientology as a charitable organization and stated that its income would be tax exempt.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3048935 |title=Scientology gets tax-exempt status |publisher=The New Zealand Herald |date=December 27, 2002 |accessdate=July 13, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66b9pHJG9?url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3048935 |archivedate=April 1, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} It has gained judicial recognition in Italy,{{harvnb|Richardson|2009|p=291}}{{clarify|date=April 2015}} and Scientology officials have won the right to perform marriages in South Africa.Gallagher, Eugene V.; Ashcraft, W. Michael (2006). [https://books.google.com/books?id=oZiScvbS6-cC&pg=PA185&dq=Eugene+Gallagher+scientology&num=100#PRA4-PA185,M1 Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America], {{ISBN|978-0-275-98712-1}}, p. 185 Scientology is not recognized as a religion in Canada. In the UK, the [[Charity Commission for England and Wales]] ruled in 1999 that Scientology was not a religion and refused to register the Church as a charity, although a year later, it was recognized as a not-for-profit body in a separate proceeding by the UK [[Revenue and Customs]] and exempted from UK [[value added tax]].Harry Wallop: {{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2006/08/11/cntax11.xml |title=Scientology tax victory could cost Revenue millions |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501091513/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fmoney%2F2006%2F08%2F11%2Fcntax11.xml |archivedate=May 1, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}, [[Daily Telegraph]], August 11, 2006 In December 2013, the United Kingdom's highest court officially recognized Scientology as a religion. The ruling ended a five-year legal battle by Scientologist Louisa Hodkin, who sought the legal right to marry at the Church of Scientology chapel in central London. The opinion by five supreme court justices redefined religion in law, rendering the 1970 definition "out of date" in restricting religious worship to "reverence or veneration of God or of a Supreme Being."{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/12/11/uk-britain-scientology-idUKBRE9BA0CQ20131211 | work=Reuters | title=UK Supreme Court says Scientology is a religion, allows wedding | date=December 11, 2013}}{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10510301/Scientology-is-a-religion-rules-Supreme-Court.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=John | last=Bingham | title=Scientology is a religion, rules Supreme Court | date=December 11, 2013| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140401072938/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10510301/Scientology-is-a-religion-rules-Supreme-Court.html | archivedate=April 1, 2014 }}[http://rt.com/news/line/2013-12-11/ December 11, 2013 – RT News] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211000651/http://rt.com/news/line/2013-12-11/ |date=December 11, 2013 }}{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/12/britain-scientology-religion_n_4432265.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Yasmine | last=Hafiz | title=Britain Recognizes Scientology As A Religion | date=December 12, 2013| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216051803/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/12/britain-scientology-religion_n_4432265.html?utm_hp_ref=religion | archivedate=December 16, 2013 }} ===Viewed as a commercial enterprise=== {{Main|Scientology as a business}} [[File:Berlin-Scientology-2007.jpg|thumb|Scientology desk near the [[Potsdamer Platz]] in Berlin]] Scientology has been accused of being "a business, often given to criminal acts, and sometimes masquerading as a religion." In conjunction with the Church of Scientology's request to be officially recognized as a religion in Germany, around 1996 the German state [[Baden-Württemberg]] conducted a thorough investigation of the group's activities within Germany.[https://web.archive.org/web/20030831131002/http://www.im.nrw.de/inn/doks/vs/blagsc.pdf Zur Frage der Beobachtung der Scientology-Organisation durch die Verfassungsschutzbehörden] (in German) (PDF format) The results of this investigation indicated that at the time of publication, Scientology's main sources of revenue ("Haupteinnahmequellen der SO") were from course offerings and sales of their various publications. Course offerings ranged from (German Marks) DM 182.50 to about DM 30,000{{spaced ndash}}the equivalent today of approximately $119 to $19,560 USD. Revenue from monthly, bi-monthly, and other membership offerings could not be estimated in the report, but was nevertheless placed in the millions. Defending its practices against accusations of [[profiteering (business)|profiteering]], the Church has countered critics by drawing analogies to other religious groups who have established practices such as [[tithing]], or require members to make donations for specific religious services.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=60}} Since 1997 [[Germany]] has considered Scientology to be in conflict with the principles of the nation's constitution. It is seen as an anticonstitutional sect and a new version of political extremism and because there is "evidence for intentions against the free democratic basic order" it is observed by the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution.{{cite web|url=http://www.verfassungsschutz.de/de/arbeitsfelder/af_scientology|title=Scientology-Organisation|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210023427/http://www.verfassungsschutz.de/de/arbeitsfelder/af_scientology/|archivedate=February 10, 2013 }}{{de icon }}{{cite web|url=http://www.heute.de/ZDF/zdfportal/web/heute-Nachrichten/4672/23818856/5cf9d6/Eskalierende-Gewaltkultur-bei-Scientology.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120921005615/http://www.heute.de/ZDF/zdfportal/web/heute-Nachrichten/4672/23818856/5cf9d6/Eskalierende-Gewaltkultur-bei-Scientology.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 21, 2012 |title="Eskalierende Gewaltkultur" bei Scientology – heute-Nachrichten |publisher=Heute.de |accessdate=September 20, 2012}} In 1997, an open letter to then-German Chancellor, [[Helmut Kohl]], published as a newspaper advertisement in the ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'', drew parallels between the "organized oppression" of [[Scientology in Germany|Scientologists in Germany]] and the treatment of [[Jews]] in 1930s' [[Nazi]] Germany.Schmid, John (January 15, 1997). {{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/1997/01/15/scient.t.php |title=German Party Replies To Scientology Backers |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228220902/http://iht.com/articles/1997/01/15/scient.t.php |archivedate=February 28, 2009 }}, ''[[International Herald Tribune|Herald Tribune]]'' The letter was signed by [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Goldie Hawn]] and a number of other [[Hollywood]] celebrities and executives.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-704081.html |title=Germany, America and Scientology |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610085859/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-704081.html |archivedate=June 10, 2014 }}, ''Washington Post'', February 1, 1997Bonfante, Jordan; van Voorst, Bruce (February 10, 1997). "{{cite magazine|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,985883-1,00.html |title=Does Germany Have Something Against These Guys? |magazine=Time |date=February 10, 1997 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130520120328/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C985883-1%2C00.html |archivedate=May 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}", ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' Commenting on the matter, a spokesman for the U.S. [[Department of State]] said that Scientologists were discriminated against in Germany, but condemned the comparisons to the Nazis' treatment of Jews as extremely inappropriate, as did a [[United Nations Special Rapporteur]].Staff (April 2, 1998). "{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9900E6DD163AF931A35757C0A96E958260 |title=U.N. Derides Scientologists' Charges About German 'Persecution' |work=The New York Times |date=April 2, 1998}}", ''[[New York Times]]'' Based on the IRS exemptions, the [[U.S. State Department]] formally criticized Germany for discriminating against Scientologists and began to note Scientologists' complaints of harassment in its annual [[human rights]] reports, as well as the annual [[International Religious Freedom Act#Office of International Religious Freedom|International Religious Freedom Reports]] it has released from 1999 onwards.{{cite book|author1=Peter Beyer|author2=Lori G. Beaman|title=Religion, globalization and culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BO9csuSoYscC&pg=PA274|accessdate=October 10, 2010|year=2007|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-15407-0|page=274}} Germany will continue to monitor Scientology's activities in the country, despite continued objection from Scientology which cites such monitoring as abuse of freedom of religion.{{cite news|title=Germany drops attempt to ban Scientology|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27843485/|publisher=[[msnbc.com]]|accessdate=July 13, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121031060139/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27843485/|archivedate=October 31, 2012}} France and Belgium have not recognized Scientology as a religion, and [[Stephen A. Kent]], writing in 2001, noted that recognition had not been obtained in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Israel]] or [[Mexico]] either.{{harvnb|Kent|2001|p=}} The Belgian State Prosecution Service has recommended that various individuals and organizations associated with Scientology should be prosecuted.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,295693,00.html |title=Church of Scientology Faces Criminal Charges in Belgium – International News |publisher=FOXNews.com |date=September 4, 2007 |accessdate=September 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119132742/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C295693%2C00.html |archivedate=November 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|first=Roland|last=Planchar|title=La Scientologie plus près de son procès|url=http://www.lalibre.be/article.phtml?id=10&subid=90&art_id=368037|publisher=La Libre Belgique|date=September 4, 2007|accessdate=May 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016103911/http://lalibre.be/article.phtml?id=10&subid=90&art_id=368037|archivedate=October 16, 2007|language=fr}} An administrative court has yet to decide if charges will be pressed. In Greece, Scientology is not recognized as a religion by the Greek government, and multiple applications for religious status have been denied, notably in 2000 and 2003.{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2004/35458.htm |title=US Dept of State International Religious Freedom Report 2004 |publisher=State.gov |date=January 1, 2004 |accessdate=September 4, 2010 }} In the [[Netherlands]], Scientology was granted tax exempt status in October 2013.{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2013/10/18/netherlands-court-provides-some-legitimacy-to-scientology/|title=Scientology tax-exempt in Netherlands|date=October 18, 2013|accessdate=February 19, 2014|agency=Associated Press|work=New York Post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211133643/http://nypost.com/2013/10/18/netherlands-court-provides-some-legitimacy-to-scientology/|archivedate=December 11, 2013}} The status was revoked in October 2015. The court ruled that because auditing fees and course costs were more expensive than most commercial education institutions, Scientology appeared to be aimed at making a profit.{{cite news|last1=Pieters|first1=Janene|title=Hague Court Deal Blow to Scientology Tax-Free Status|url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2015/10/22/hague-court-deals-blow-to-scientology-tax-free-status/|accessdate=March 15, 2016|work=NL Times|date=October 22, 2015}}{{cite web|title=ECLI:NL:GHDHA:2015:2875 |url=http://uitspraken.rechtspraak.nl/inziendocument?id=ECLI:NL:GHDHA:2015:2875 |publisher=Gerechtshof Den Haag |accessdate=March 15, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107214403/http://uitspraken.rechtspraak.nl/inziendocument?id=ECLI%3ANL%3AGHDHA%3A2015%3A2875 |archivedate=November 7, 2015 |language=Dutch |date=October 21, 2015 |dead-url=no |df= }} Scientology maintains strict control over the use of its symbols, icons, and names. It claims [[copyright]] and [[trademark]] over its "Scientology cross", and its lawyers have threatened lawsuits against individuals and organizations who have published the image in books and on Web sites. Because of this, it is very difficult for individual groups to attempt to publicly practice Scientology on their own, independent of the official Church of Scientology. Scientology has filed suit against a number of individuals who have attempted to set up their own auditing practices, using copyright and trademark law to shut these groups down.Plotkin-Wells & Wimmer ''E-Commerce Law & Business'', Section 8.01[2], Aspen Publishers Online, 2003 {{ISBN|978-0-7355-4148-1}} The Church of Scientology and its many related organizations have amassed considerable real estate holdings worldwide, likely in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Scientology encourages existing members to "sell" Scientology to others by paying a commission to those who recruit new members. Scientology franchises, or missions, must pay the Church of Scientology roughly 10% of their gross income.{{cite news|first=Joel |last=Sappell |author2=Welkos, Robert W. |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/la-scientologysideb062490,1,7772622.story |title=The Man In Control |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |page=A41:4 |date=June 24, 1990 |accessdate=June 6, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602090122/http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/la-scientologysideb062490%2C1%2C7772622.story |archivedate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On that basis, it is likened to a [[pyramid selling scheme]].{{cite web|last=West|first=Louis Jolyon|title=Psychiatry and Scientology|date=July 1990|url=http://www.solitarytrees.net/pubs/psyscn.htm|accessdate=May 16, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66b9qO8BA?url=http://www.solitarytrees.net/pubs/psyscn.htm|archivedate=April 1, 2012}} While introductory courses do not cost much, courses at the higher levels may cost several thousand dollars each.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=59}} As a rule, the great majority of members proceeds up the bridge in a steady rate commensurate with their income. Most recently the Italian Supreme Court agreed with the American IRS that the church's financial system is analogous to the practices of other groups and not out of line with its religious purposes.Melton, J. Gordon (2000). The Church of Scientology. Salt Lake City: Signature Press. {{ISBN|978-1-56085-139-4}} In November 2009, Australian [[Australian Senate|Senator]] [[Nick Xenophon]] used a speech in Federal Parliament to allege that the Church of Scientology is a criminal organization. Based on letters from former followers of the religion, he said that there were "allegations of forced imprisonment, coerced abortions, and embezzlement of church funds, of physical violence and intimidation, blackmail and the widespread and deliberate abuse of information obtained by the organization".{{cite journal|title=Rudd's concerns about Scientology (quoted from embedded video, "Xenophon attacks Scientology – Independent Senator Nick Xenophon attacks Scientology as a 'criminal organisation{{Single double}})|date=November 18, 2009|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/senator-attacks--criminal-church-of-scientology-20091118-ikla.html?autostart=1|publisher=[[The Age]]|ref=harv|postscript=}} ==Scientology in religious studies== Describing the available scholarship on Scientology, [[David G. Bromley]] and [[Douglas E. Cowan]] stated in 2006 that "most scholars have concluded that Scientology falls within the category of religion for the purposes of academic study, and a number have defended the Church in judicial and political proceedings on this basis." Hugh B. Urban writes that "Scientology's efforts to get itself defined as a religion make it an ideal case study for thinking about how we understand and define religion."Urban, Hugh B.: The Church of Scientology: A History of a New Religion Chapman, Mark. Review of Religious Research. 2013. vol. 55. Issue: 1, pp. 203-204 Toward the second decade of the 2000s, a new interest for Scientology emerged among scholars, bringing the subject from obscurity.{{cite journal |title=Alternative Spirituality and Religion Review |publisher=University Charles De Gaulle Lille |year=2014 |last=Dericquebourg |first=Regis |volume=4 |issue=1 }} According to the ''Encyclopedia of Religious Controversies in the United States'', "even as Scientology raises questions about how and who gets to define religion, most scholars recognize it as a religion, one that emerges from and builds on American individualism and the spiritual marketplace that dominated 1950s America."{{cite encyclopedia | last = Neal | first = Lynn S. | editor = Bill J. Leonard and Jill Y. Crainshaw | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Religious Controversies in the United States | title = Scientology | edition = 2nd | year = 2013 | publisher = ABC-CLIO | volume = 2 | location = Santa Barbara, CA | pages = 697–699}} David G. Bromley comments that Scientology "could gain strength by adding to the new perspective on existence, the hope and human meaning that only a transcendent creed can give."{{cite book |last=Bromley |first1=David G. |title=The Future of New Religious Movements |publisher=Mercer University Press |year=1987 }} Bromley and Cowan noted in 2008 that Scientology's attempts "to gain favor with new religion scholars" had often been problematic. According to Religious Studies professor Mary Farrell Benarowski, Scientology describes itself as drawing on science, religion, psychology and philosophy but "had been claimed by none of them and repudiated, for the most part, by all."{{cite book|first=Mary Farrell |last=Bednarowski |chapter=The Church of Scientology: Lightning Rod for Cultural Boundary Conflicts |editor=Timothy Miller |title=America's Alternative Religions|year=1995 |isbn=978-0-7914-2397-4|publisher=SUNY Press|page=388}} Regis Dericquesbourg writes about the efficacy of Scientology in imparting knowledge: "Scientology indeed not only brings knowledge, it also brings personal introspection through auditing, and transmission in upper levels is not merely reading texts: what is transmitted is experienced through a solo or duo auditing experience." He compared it to psychoanalysis.{{cite journal |title=Alternative Spirituality and Religion Review |journal=University Charles de Gaulle Lille |year=2014 |last=Dericquebourg |first=Regis |volume=4 |issue=1 }} Frank K. Flinn, adjunct professor of religious studies at [[Washington University]] in [[St. Louis]] wrote, "it is abundantly clear that Scientology has both the typical forms of ceremonial and celebratory worship and its own unique form of spiritual life."{{cite web|url=http://www.neuereligion.de/ENG/Flinn/index.htm|first=Frank K.|last=Flinn|title=Scientology: The Marks of Religion|publisher=Church of Scientology|date=September 22, 1994 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120914201545/http://www.neuereligion.de/ENG/Flinn/index.htm|archivedate=September 14, 2012}} Flinn further states that religion requires "beliefs in something transcendental or ultimate, practices (rites and codes of behavior) that re-inforce those beliefs and, a community that is sustained by both the beliefs and practices", all of which are present within Scientology. Similarly, ''World Religions in America'' states that "Scientology contains the same elements of most other religions, including myths, scriptures, doctrines, worship, sacred practices and rituals, moral and ethical expectations, a community of believers, clergy, and ecclesiastic organizations."{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=34vGv_HDGG8C|title=World Religions in America, Fourth Edition: An Introduction|last=DeChant|first=Dell|last2=Jorgensen|first2=Danny L.|date=October 7, 2009|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|isbn=9781611640472|editor-last=Neusner|editor-first=Jacob|page=297|language=en}} While acknowledging that a number of his colleagues accept Scientology as a religion, sociologist [[Stephen A. Kent]] writes: "Rather than struggling over whether or not to label Scientology as a religion, I find it far more helpful to view it as a multifaceted transnational corporation, only ''one'' element of which is religious" [emphasis in the original].{{cite journal|author=Beit-Hallahmi, Benjamin|title=Scientology: Religion or racket?|publisher=Marburg Journal of Religion|date=September 2003|format=PDF|url=http://www.uni-marburg.de/fb03/ivk/mjr/pdfs/2003/articles/breit2003.pdf|volume=8|issue=1|accessdate=July 1, 2014}}{{cite journal|author=Kent, Stephen|title=Scientology – Is this a Religion?|publisher=Marburg Journal of Religion|date=July 1999|url=http://www.uni-marburg.de/fb03/ivk/mjr/pdfs/1999/articles/kent1999.pdf|volume=4|issue=1|accessdate=July 1, 2014}} Donna Batten in the ''Gale Encyclopedia of American Law'' writes, "A belief does not need to be stated in traditional terms to fall within [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] protection. For example, Scientology—a system of beliefs that a human being is essentially a free and immortal spirit who merely inhabits a body—does not propound the existence of a supreme being, but it qualifies as a religion under the broad definition propounded by the Supreme Court."{{cite book|editor1=Jeffrey Lehman |editor2=Shirelle Phelps |title=West's Encyclopedia of American Law |chapter=Religion |edition= 2nd |year=2005 |publisher=Thomson/Gale |volume=8 |location=Detroit |page=283 |isbn=978-0-7876-6375-9}} J. Gordon Melton asserts that while the debate over definitions of religion will continue, "scholars will probably continue in the future to adopt a broad definition, thus including Scientology in a wider religious field."{{cite book |last1=Melton |first1=J. Gordon |title=Studies in Contemporary Religion: The Church of Scientology |editors=Massimo Introvigne |url=http://signaturebooks.com/2010/02/the-church-of-scientology-studies-in-contemporary-religion/ |publisher=Signature Books |year=2000 |isbn=978-1-56085-139-4 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=July 29, 2013 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130801081431/http://signaturebooks.com/2010/02/the-church-of-scientology-studies-in-contemporary-religion/ |archivedate=August 1, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} The material contained in the OT levels has been characterized as bad science fiction by critics, while others claim it bears structural similarities to [[gnosticism|gnostic]] thought and ancient Hindu beliefs of creation and cosmic struggle.{{cite book|last=Herrick|first=James A. |authorlink=James A. Herrick|title=The Making of the New Spirituality|publisher=InterVarsity Press|year=2004|location=Downers Grove, IL|page=199|isbn=978-0-8308-3279-8}} Melton suggests that these elements of the OT levels may never have been intended as descriptions of historical events and that, like other religious mythology, they may have their truth in the realities of the body and mind which they symbolize. He adds that on whatever level Scientologists might have received this mythology, they seem to have found it useful in their spiritual quest.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|p=33}} Scholar Luigi Berzano of the University of Turin listed five religious characteristics of Scientology: a set of doctrines leading to a spiritual goal, a community of believers, an authority figure (Hubbard), ritual practices, and "an ethical-moral view of life."{{cite journal |title=Is Scientology a Religion? |journal=The Journal of CESNUR |year=2018 |last=Berzano |first=Luigi |volume=2 |issue=2 |issn=2532-2990 }} ===Hubbard's motives=== During his lifetime, Hubbard was accused of using religion as a façade for Scientology to maintain [[tax exemption|tax-exempt]] status and avoid prosecution for false medical claims.{{cite journal|last=Beit-Hallahmi|first=Benjamin|title=Scientology: Religion or racket?|journal=Marburg Journal of Religion|volume=8|issue=1|date=September 2003|url=http://web.uni-marburg.de/religionswissenschaft/journal/mjr/beit.html|accessdate=June 30, 2006|ref=harv }} The IRS cited a statement frequently attributed to Hubbard that the way to get rich was to found a religion.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|pp=55, 74}} Though some claim the statement is unsubstantiated, many of Hubbard's science fiction colleagues, including [[Sam Merwin Jr.|Sam Merwin]], [[Lloyd Arthur Eshbach]] and [[Sam Moskowitz|Sam Moscowitz]], recall Hubbard raising the topic in conversation.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/939141508|title=Over my shoulder : reflections on a science fiction era|last=1910-2003.|first=Eshbach, Lloyd Arthur,|date=1983|publisher=O. Train|isbn=9781880418116|location=Philadelphia|oclc=939141508}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/17481843|title=Bare-faced messiah : the true story of L. Ron Hubbard|last=Russell.|first=Miller,|date=1988|origyear=1987|publisher=H. Holt|isbn=978-0805006544|edition= 1st American |location=New York|oclc=17481843}} Hubbard grew up in a climate that was very critical of organized religion, and frequently quoted anti-religious sentiments in his early lectures.{{cite journal | last = Frenschkowski | first = Marco | title = Researching Scientology: Some Observations on Recent Literature, English and German | journal = Alternative Spirituality and Religion Review | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | page = 38 | date = January 1, 2010 | url = http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/acpub/asrr/2010/00000001/00000001/art00001 | issn = 1946-0538 | doi = | id = | accessdate = January 13, 2011 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20140227165504/http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/acpub/asrr/2010/00000001/00000001/art00001| archivedate =February 27, 2014}} The scholar Marco Frenschkowski ([[University of Mainz]]) has stated that it was not easy for Hubbard "to come to terms with the spiritual side of his own movement. Hubbard did not want to found a religion: he discovered that what he was talking about in fact was religion. This mainly happened when he had to deal with apparent memories from former lives. He had to defend himself about this to his friends." Frenschkowski allows that there were practical concerns in the question of "how to present Scientology to the outside world", but dismisses the notion that the religious format was just an expedient pretense; Frenschkowski points to many passages in Hubbard's works that document his struggle with this question. Frenschkowski suggests that it was a biographical mistake to suggest that Hubbard only became interested in Scientology as a religion in 1954. He notes that Hubbard discussed religion and the concept of God even in the years leading up to the emergence of Scientology, and that he did not "rush into religion" but rather, "discovered it through the development of his work with pre-clears." Drawing parallels to similar struggles for identity in other religious movements such as [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]] and [[Transcendental Meditation]], Frenschkowski sees in Hubbard's lectures "the case of a man whose background was non-religious and who nevertheless discovers that his ideas somehow oscillate between 'science' (in a very popular sense), 'religion' and 'philosophy', and that these ideas somehow fascinate so many people that they start to form a separate movement." Hubbard experiments with traditional religious language in a short piece written in 1953 called "The Factors", "a basic expression of Scientologist cosmology and metaphysics", reprinted in current Scientology literature. Frenschkowski observes that the text is partly biblical in structure and that this development is a component of Scientology's metamorphosis into a religion, written at a point when the nature of the new movement was unclear.{{cite journal |title=Images of Religions and Religious History in the Works of L. Ron Hubbard |journal=Alternative Spirituality and Religion Review |year=2016 |last=Frenschkowski |first=Marco|doi=10.5840/asrr20166620 |volume=7 |pages=111–153}} The Church of Scientology denounces the idea of Hubbard starting a religion for personal gain as an unfounded rumor.Platvoet & Molendijk ''The Pragmatics of Defining Religion'', pp. 63–64, Brill, 1999 {{ISBN|978-90-04-11544-6}} The Church also suggests that the origin of the rumor was a remark by [[George Orwell]] which had been misattributed to Hubbard.{{cite web|last=Jentzsch|first=Heber|title=Church of Scientology FAQ: Did L. Ron Hubbard state that the way to make money was to start a religion?|url=http://faq.scientology.org/page44b.htm|accessdate=June 9, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223234041/http://faq.scientology.org/page44b.htm|archivedate=February 23, 2012}} [[Robert Vaughn Young]], who left the Church in 1989 after being its spokesman for twenty years, suggested that reports of Hubbard making such a statement could be explained as a misattribution, despite having encountered three of Hubbard's associates from his science fiction days who remembered Hubbard making statements of that sort in person. It was Young who by a stroke of luck came up with the "Orwell quote": "but I have always thought there might be a lot of cash in starting a new religion, and we'll talk it over some time". It appears in a letter by [[Eric Blair]] (known the world as George Orwell) to his friend, Jack Common, dated 16-February-38 (February 16, 1938), and was published in ''Collected Essays, Journalism and Letters of George Orwell'', vol. 1.''The Collected Essays, Journalism and Letters of George Orwell'' (4 volumes), vol. 1, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1968 ASIN: B000GLJ10S In 2006, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s Janet Reitman also attributed the statement to Hubbard, as a remark to science fiction writer [[Lloyd Eshbach]] and recorded in Eshbach's autobiography.Janet Reitman ''Inside Scientology'', Rolling Stone, February 23, 2006 ===Scientology as a UFO religion=== Scientology can be seen as a [[UFO religion]] in which the existence of extraterrestrial entities operating unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are an element of belief. In this context, it is discussed in ''UFO Religions'' by Christopher Partridge,{{Citation | last=Partridge | first=Christopher Hugh | year=2003 | title=UFO religions | publisher=Routledge | isbn=978-0-415-26323-8 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Aqhdas-u1UgC}} and ''The Encyclopedic Sourcebook of UFO Religions'' by [[James R. Lewis (scholar)|James R. Lewis]],{{cite book | last =Lewis | first =James R. (editor) | authorlink =James R. Lewis (scholar) | title =The Encyclopedic Sourcebook of UFO Religions | publisher =Prometheus Books | date =November 2003 | isbn =978-1-57392-964-6 | page =42 }} while Susan Palmer draws several parallels with [[Raelianism]].Palmer, Susan J. ''Aliens adored : Raël's UFO religion'', Rutgers University Press, 2004, {{ISBN|978-0-8135-3475-6}} Gregory Reece, in his book ''UFO Religion: Inside flying saucer cults and culture'', writes:
Scientology is unique within the UFO culture because of this secretiveness, as well as because of the capitalist format under which they operate. Scientology is also difficult to categorize. While it bears strong similarities to the [[Ashtar (extraterrestrial being)|Ashtar Command]] or the [[Aetherius Society]], its emphasis upon the Xenu event as the central message of the group seems to place them within the [[ancient astronaut]] tradition. Either way, Scientology is perhaps most different from other UFO groups in their attempt to keep all of the space opera stuff under wraps. They really would have preferred the rest of us not to know about [[Xenu]] and the galactic federation. Alas, such secrets are hard to keepReece, G.l., ''UFO Religion: Inside Flying Saucer Cults and Culture'', I.B.Tauris & Co Ltd, 2007, pp. 182-186.
Regardless of such statements by critics, Hubbard wrote and lectured openly about the material he himself called "space opera." In 1952, Hubbard published a book (''[[Scientology: A History of Man|What to Audit / A History of Man]]''{{cite web|title = Scientology: A History of Man {{!}} Bridge Publications, Inc|url = http://www.bridgepub.com/store/catalog/scientology-a-history-of-man-hardcover.html|website = www.bridgepub.com|accessdate = May 8, 2015}}) on space opera and other material that may be encountered when auditing preclears.Church of Scientology, "[http://www.scientology.org/wis/wiseng/42/52.htm Complete List of Scientology and Dianetics Books and Materials of 1952]".{{Cite book|title = Scientology|last = Rothstein|first = Mikael|publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 2009|isbn = 978-0-19-533149-3|location = New York, New York|page = 375|editor-last = Lewis|editor-first = James R.}} According to [[David G. Bromley]], Scientology is "part therapy, part religion, part UFO group. It's a mix of things unlike any other religious group out there." Scholar Andreas Grunschlo writes that as a ufogical religion, Scientology "conceives of earthly human beings primarily as extraterrestrial spirits ('Thetans') which have now to put on their 'bridge to freedom' again —a soul conception which is paralleled by the typical ufogical 'star seeds' or 'walk-ins' planted on this earthly 'garden' for spiritual growth."{{cite book |last=Lewis |first1=James R. |title=The Oxford Handbook of New Religious Movements |volume=1 |editor-last=Lewis |editor-first=James R. |publisher=OUP USA |year=2008 |isbn=9780195369649 }}   ===Influences=== The general orientation of Hubbard's philosophy owes much to [[Will Durant]], author of the popular 1926 classic ''[[The Story of Philosophy]]''; ''Dianetics'' is dedicated to Durant. Hubbard's view of a mechanically functioning mind in particular finds close parallels in Durant's work on [[Spinoza]].{{harvnb|Willms|2009|pp=248–249}} According to Hubbard himself, Scientology is "the Western anglicized continuance of many early forms of wisdom."{{cite book |last=Ankerberg |first1=John |last2=Weldon|first2=John |title=Encyclopedia of New Age Beliefs|publisher=Harvest House Publishers |date=1996 }} Ankerberg and Weldon mention the sources of Scientology to include "the [[Vedas]], [[Buddhism]], [[Judaism]], [[Gnosticism]], [[Taoism]], early Greek civilization and the teachings of [[Jesus]], [[Nietzsche]] and Freud."{{cite journal | title = The concept "salvation" in the Church of Scientology | journal = HTS Teologiese Studies / Theological Studies | year = 2006 | first = S.P. | last = Pretorius | volume = 62 | issue = 1 | pages = 313–327| id = | doi=10.4102/hts.v62i1.353}} Hubbard asserted that Freudian thought was a "major precursor" to Scientology. W. Vaughn Mccall, Professor and Chairman of the Georgia Regents University writes, "Both Freudian theory and Hubbard assume that there are unconscious mental processes that may be shaped by early life experiences, and that these influence later behavior and thought." Both schools of thought propose a "tripartite structure of the mind."{{cite journal |title=Psychiatry and Psychology in the Writings of L. Ron Hubbard |journal=Journal of Religion and Health |year=2007 |last=Mccall |first=W. Vaughn|volume=46 |issue=3 |pages=437–47 |doi=10.1007/s10943-006-9079-9}} [[Sigmund Freud]]'s psychology, popularized in the 1930s and 1940s, was a key contributor to the Dianetics therapy model, and was acknowledged unreservedly as such by Hubbard in his early works. Hubbard never forgot, when he was 12 years old, meeting Cmdr. [[Joseph Cheesman Thompson]], a U.S. Navy officer who had studied with FreudLewis & Petersen ''Controversial New Religions'', p. 238, Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-19-515682-9}} and when writing to the [[American Psychological Association]] in 1949, he stated that he was conducting research based on the "early work of Freud".{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|p=171}} In ''Dianetics'', Hubbard cites [[Hegel]] as a negative influence — an object lesson in "confusing" writing.Hubbard, L Ron. 'Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health'. Los Angeles, California: Bridge Publications, 2007: 3. {{ISBN|978-1-4031-4484-3}} According to Mary A. Mann, Scientology is considered nondenominational, accepting all people regardless of their religions background, ethnicity, or educational attainment.{{cite book |last=Mann |first1=Mary A. |url=https://books.google.com/?id=m-pit1X2O6UC&dq=scientology |title=Science and Spirituality |year=2004 |accessdate=December 14, 2015 |isbn=9781418492946 }} Another major influence was [[Alfred Korzybski]]'s [[General Semantics]]. Hubbard was friends with fellow science fiction writer [[A. E. van Vogt]], who explored the implications of Korzybski's [[non-Aristotelian logic]] in works such as ''[[The World of Null-A]]'', and Hubbard's view of the ''reactive mind'' has clear and acknowledged parallels with Korzybski's thought; in fact, Korzybski's "anthropometer" may have been what inspired Hubbard's invention of the [[E-meter]]. Beyond that, Hubbard himself named a great many other influences in his own writing – in ''Scientology 8-8008'', for example, these include philosophers from [[Anaxagoras]] and [[Aristotle]] to [[Herbert Spencer]] and [[Voltaire]], physicists and mathematicians like [[Euclid]] and [[Isaac Newton]], as well as founders of religions such as [[Buddha]], [[Confucius]], [[Jesus]] and [[Mohammed]] – but there is little evidence in Hubbard's writings that he studied these figures to any great depth.{{harvnb|Willms|2005|pp=54–60}} As noted, elements of the Eastern religions are evident in Scientology, in particular the concept of [[karma]] found [[Karma in Hinduism|in Hinduism]] and [[Karma in Jainism|Jainism]].Bryan Wilson (1995): ''{{cite web |url=http://www.neuereligion.de/ENG/collection/diversity/point33.htm |title=Religious Toleration & Religious Diversity |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031204601/http://www.neuereligion.de/ENG/collection/diversity/point33.htm |archivedate=October 31, 2013 }}'', The Institute for the Study of American Religion.James R. Lewis ''The Oxford Handbook of New Religious Movements'', p. 429, Oxford University Press US, 2004 {{ISBN|978-0-19-514986-9}} In addition to the links to Hindu texts, Scientology draws from [[Taoism]] and [[Buddhism]].Kent, Stephen A. {{cite web |url=http://www.arts.ualberta.ca/~skent/Linkedfiles/Scientology%27s%20Relationship%20With%20Eastern%20Religious%20Traditions%20.htm |title=Scientology's Relationship With Eastern Religious Traditions |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902204426/http://www.arts.ualberta.ca/~skent/Linkedfiles/Scientology%27s%20Relationship%20With%20Eastern%20Religious%20Traditions%20.htm |archivedate=September 2, 2012 }}, ''[[Journal of Contemporary Religion]]'', Vol. 11, No. 1, 1996, page 21 According to the ''Encyclopedia of Community'', Scientology "shows affinities with Buddhism and a remarkable similarity to first-century Gnosticism."Karen Christensen, David Levinson (2003): ''Encyclopedia of Community'', SAGE, p. 1210: "Scientology shows affinities with Buddhism and a remarkable similarity to first-century [[Gnosticism]]."[[John A. Saliba]] (1996): ''Signs of the Times'', Médiaspaul, p. 51 In the 1940s, Hubbard was in contact with [[John Whiteside Parsons|Jack Parsons]], a rocket scientist and member of the [[Ordo Templi Orientis]] then led by [[Aleister Crowley]], and there have been suggestions that this connection influenced some of the ideas and symbols of Scientology.{{harvnb|Willms|2009|p=259}} Religious scholars [[Gerald Willms]] and [[J. Gordon Melton]] have stated that Crowley's teachings bear little if any resemblance to Scientology doctrine.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|pp=7–8, 67}} J. Gordon Melton writes that Scientology has its roots in Esoteric thought. He cited the significance of understanding Scientology's appeal as aligned with Esoteric tradition. The Church is a "significant revision" and "meaningful revitalization" within the esoteric tradition. Melton states that Scientology can also be traced back to Gnosticism, Manicheanism, Freemasonry and Theosophy.{{cite conference |last=Melton |first=J. Gordon |title=Acta Comparanda |language=English, French |url=http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |booktitle=On doing research on Scientology |conference=International Conference – Scientology in a scholarly perspective 24-25th January 2014 |publisher=University of Antwerp, Faculty for Comparative Study of Religions and Humanism |place=Antwerp, Belgium |year=2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216050903/http://www.observatoire-religion.com/2016/12/scientology-in-a-scholarly-perspective/ |archivedate=February 16, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} According to [[James R. Lewis (scholar)|James R. Lewis]], Scientology is in the same lineage of [[supernatural]] religious movements such as [[New Thought]]. Scientology goes beyond this and refers to their religio-therapeutic practices as religious technology. Lewis wrote, "Scientology sees their psycho-spiritual technology as supplying the missing ingredient in existing technologies—namely, the therapeutic engineering of the human psyche."{{cite book | last1 = Lewis | first1 = James R. | title = Scientology | publisher = Oxford University Press | date = March 2009 | location = Cary, NC | isbn = 978-0-19-533149-3}} ===Scientology and hypnosis=== {{Main|Scientology and hypnosis}} Hubbard was said to be an accomplished hypnotist, and close acquaintances such as [[Forrest Ackerman]] (Hubbard's literary agent) and [[A. E. van Vogt]] (an early supporter of Dianetics) witnessed repeated demonstrations of his hypnotic skills.{{cite book|author=Miller, Russell|title=Bare-faced Messiah, The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|publisher=Henry Holt & Co|location=New York|edition= First American|year=1987|isbn=978-0-8050-0654-4 |pages=140–142|url=http://www.clambake.org/archive/books/bfm/bfmconte.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312081721/http://www.clambake.org/archive/books/bfm/bfmconte.htm|archivedate=March 12, 2011}} Scientology literature states that L. Ron Hubbard expertise in [[hypnosis]] led to the discovery of the [[Engram (Dianetics)|Dianetic engram]].{{cite web|title = Is Scientology like hypnotism, meditation, psychotherapy or other mental therapies?|url = http://www.scientology.org/faq/scientology-and-other-practices/is-scientology-like-hypnotism-meditation-psychotherapy.html|website = www.scientology.org|accessdate = December 29, 2015|language = en-US}}{{Cite book|title = The Church of Scientology: A History of a New Religion|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=8lgHtauc5R4C|publisher = Princeton University Press|date = August 22, 2011|isbn = 978-0691146089|first = Hugh B.|last = Urban}} However, Hubbard wrote that hypnosis is a "wild variable", and compared parlor hypnosis to an atom bomb.{{cite book|last1=Hubbard|first1=L. Ron|title=Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health|date=1968|publisher=Advanced Organization Saint Hill Denmark|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=16a6IZiAwIUC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q=wild%20variable&f=false|location=Copenhagen, Denmark|page=72|isbn=978-87-87347-19-8|ref=dmsmh_72}} He also wrote:{{quote|Hypnotism plants, by positive suggestion, one or another form of insanity. It is usually a temporary planting, but sometimes the hypnotic suggestion will not "lift" or remove in a way desirable to the hypnotist.{{cite book|last1=Hubbard|first1=L. Ron|title=Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health|date=1968|publisher=Advanced Organization Saint Hill Denmark|location=Copenhagen, Denmark|page=82|isbn=978-87-87347-19-8|ref=dmsmh_82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=16a6IZiAwIUC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA82#v=onepage&q=hypnosis&f=false}}}} ===Etymology of "Scientology" and earlier usage=== The word ''Scientology'' is a pairing of the [[Latin]] word ''scientia'' ("knowledge", "skill"), which comes from the verb ''scīre'' ("to know"), and the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] λόγος ''lógos'' ("word" or "account [of]").{{harvnb|Cusack|2009|p=394}}Benjamin J. Hubbard/John T. Hatfield/James A. Santucci ''An Educator's Classroom Guide to America's Religious Beliefs and Practices'', p. 89, Libraries Unlimited, 2007 {{ISBN|978-1-59158-409-4}} ''Scientology'', as coined by L. Ron Hubbard, comes from the Latin ''scio'', which means "knowing, in the fullest meaning of the word" and the Greek word logos, which means "study of". Scientology is further defined as "the study and handling of the spirit in relationship to itself, universes, and other life."{{cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/Library/Scientology/Origins/Beginnings.html |title=Beginnings |publisher=Patheos.com |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140402162755/http://www.patheos.com/Library/Scientology/Origins/Beginnings.html |archivedate=April 2, 2014 }} The term scientology had been used in published works at least twice before Hubbard. In ''The New Word'' (1901) poet and lawyer [[Allen Upward]] first used scientology to mean blind, unthinking acceptance of scientific doctrine.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Lc7nNIo-UukC&printsec=frontcover The New Word] original version available for download. In 1934, philosopher [[Anastasius Nordenholz]] published ''Scientology: Science of the Constitution and Usefulness of Knowledge'', which used the term to mean the [[Scientific method|science of science]].Anastasius Nordenholz ''Scientology: Science of the Constitution and Usefulness of Knowledge'', Freie Zone e. V., 1995 {{ISBN|978-3-9804724-1-8}} It is unknown whether Hubbard was aware of either prior usage of the word.The New Word, Publisher: Forgotten Books (February 7, 2008), {{ISBN|978-1-60506-811-4}} {{ISBN|978-1-60506-811-4}}The Encyclopedia of Christianity, Erwin Fahlbusch, Geoffrey W. Bromiley, page 556 ===ARC and KRC triangles=== {{See also|Scientology terminology|Scientology beliefs and practices#ARC and KRC triangle}} [[File:Scientology Symbol Logo.png|thumb|upright|The Scientology symbol is composed of the letter S, which stands for Scientology, and the ARC and KRC triangles, two important concepts in Scientology.]] The ARC and KRC triangles are [[concept map]]s which show a relationship between three concepts to form another concept. These two triangles are present in the Scientology symbol. The lower triangle, the ARC triangle, is a summary representation of the knowledge the Scientologist strives for. It encompasses '''''A'''ffinity'' (affection, love or liking), '''''R'''eality'' (consensual reality) and '''''C'''ommunication'' (the exchange of ideas). Scientology teaches that improving one of the three aspects of the triangle "increases the level" of the other two, but Communication is held to be the most important.{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|p=176}} The upper triangle is the KRC triangle, the letters KRC positing a similar relationship between '''''K'''nowledge'', '''''R'''esponsibility'' and '''''C'''ontrol''.{{cite web|url=http://www.whatisscientology.org/html/Part14/Chp50/pg1022.html |title=Scientology Glossary of Terms – K |publisher=Whatisscientology.org |accessdate=May 30, 2015 }} Among Scientologists, the letters ARC are used as an affectionate greeting in personal communication, for example at the end of a letter.{{cite web |url= http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2012/01/scientology_in_3.php |title=Scientology in Turmoil: Debbie Cook's E-Mail, Annotated |last= Ortega|first=Tony |website=[[The Village Voice]] |date=January 6, 2012 |accessdate=January 14, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214000535/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2012/01/scientology_in_3.php |archivedate=February 14, 2014 }} Social problems are ascribed to breakdowns in ARC – in other words, a lack of agreement on reality, a failure to communicate effectively, or a failure to develop affinity.{{harvnb|Cowan|Bromley|2006|p=177}} These can take the form of ''overts'' – harmful acts against another, either intentionally or by omission – which are usually followed by ''withholds'' – efforts to conceal the wrongdoing, which further increase the level of tension in the relationship. ===Bridge to total freedom=== Scientologists seek to attain spiritual development through study of Scientology materials and auditing. The subject (called ''Technology'' or ''Tech'' in [[Scientology terminology|Scientology jargon]]) is structured in a series of levels (or ''gradients'') of gradually increasing complexity. The sequence of study ("training") and auditing ("processing") levels is termed the "[[Bridge to Total Freedom]]", or simply "the Bridge". Training concerns primarily the principles and techniques of auditing. Processing is personal development through participation in auditing sessions.{{harvnb|DeChant|Jorgenson|2003|p=228}} The Church of Scientology teaches the principle of reciprocity, involving give-and-take in every human transaction.{{harvnb|Melton|2000|pp = 59–60}} Accordingly, members are required to make donations for study courses and auditing as they move up the Bridge, the amounts increasing as higher levels are reached. Participation in higher-level courses on the Bridge may cost several thousand dollars, and Scientologists usually move up the Bridge at a rate governed by their income. According to [[David G. Bromley]], religious studies professor, working toward being an "Operating Thetan" means moving up the Bridge to Total Freedom, "which at the highest level transcends material law." He further emphasizes this belief of Scientologists: "You occasionally come across people in Scientology who say they can change the material world with their mind." ==Scientology in popular culture== {{main|Scientology in popular culture}} [[File:South Park Xenu.jpg|thumb|Xenu as depicted in ''[[South Park]]'']] The 2005 ''[[South Park]]'' episode "[[Trapped in the Closet (South Park)|Trapped in the Closet]]" publicized the story of [[Xenu]], based directly on the actual Scientology [[Operating Thetan]] III document,{{cite book|editor-last=Arp|editor-first=Robert|others=William Irwin (Series Editor)|title=South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today|publisher=Blackwell Publishing (The Blackwell Philosophy & Pop Culture Series)|date=December 11, 2006|pages=27, 59, 60, 118, 120, 132, 137, 138, 140, 224|isbn=978-1-4051-6160-2|title-link=South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today}} and accompanied by an onscreen caption reading "This is what Scientologists actually believe". After explaining these beliefs, the character representing the church's president ultimately reveals to [[Stan Marsh|Stan]] that the church is in reality a [[Confidence trick|money-making scam]].{{Citation needed|date = December 2015}} [[Paul Thomas Anderson]]'s 2012 film ''[[The Master (2012 film)|The Master]]'' features a religious organization called "The Cause" that has many similarities to Scientology.{{cite web |last=Brown |first=Lane |title=So This New Paul Thomas Anderson Movie Is Definitely About Scientology, Right? |publisher=New York Media Holdings |website=NYMag.com |date=December 3, 2010 |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2009/12/so_this_new_paul_thomas_anders.html |accessdate=June 5, 2011}}{{cite web |last=Brown |first=Lane |title=Universal Passes on Paul Thomas Anderson's Scientology Movie |publisher=New York Media Holdings |website=NYMag.com |date=March 17, 2010 |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/03/why_does_paul_thomas_andersons.html |accessdate=June 5, 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/26/scientology-hollywood-film-studio |title=Church of Scientology snaps up Hollywood film studio |last=Pilkington |first=Ed |website=[[The Guardian|Guardian.co.uk]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group|Guardian News and Media Limited]] |date=April 26, 2011 |accessdate=June 12, 2011}} Also, the character of Lancaster Dodd, played by [[Philip Seymour Hoffman]] shares a physical resemblance to Scientology founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]].{{cite web |last=Yamato |first=Jen |url=http://www.film.com/movies/will-scientologists-declare-war-on-paul-thomas-andersons-the-master#fbid=Sh0pkd5XnLJ |title=Will Scientologists Declare War on Paul Thomas Anderson's The Master? |publisher=[[RealNetworks]] |website=Film.com |date=June 10, 2010 |accessdate=June 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609133843/http://www.film.com/movies/will-scientologists-declare-war-on-paul-thomas-andersons-the-master#fbid=Sh0pkd5XnLJ |archivedate=June 9, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} In April 2015, following the recent release of ''[[Going Clear (film)|Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief]]'', ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' aired a music video featuring the "Church of Neurotology", a parody of Scientology's 1990 music video "[[We Stand Tall]]".{{cite news|last1=Ortega|first1=Tony|authorlink1=Tony Ortega (journalist)|title=Saturday Night Live's genius spoof of Scientology: Lyrics and images|url=http://tonyortega.org/2015/04/05/saturday-night-lives-genius-spoof-of-scientology-last-night-lyrics-and-images/|accessdate=November 23, 2015|work=The Underground Bunker|date=April 5, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Carlson|first1=Adam|title=SNL's 'Neurotology' Skit Puts Musical Spin on Scientology|url=http://www.people.com/article/snl-spoofs-scientology-with-neurotology-skit|accessdate=November 23, 2015|work=People|date=April 5, 2015}} In November 2016, cable network A&E began airing ''[[Leah Remini: Scientology and the Aftermath]]'', a documentary series. Remini, a TV actress and star, was a member of the Church of Scientology for over 30 years and a public proponent of Scientology for years before a public falling out in 2013. She is an executive producer of the series. The series follows Remini as she explores the history and workings of the Church, discusses her experiences and interviews ex-members willing to speak out about alleged abuses of the Church. The initial episode drew 2.1 million viewers.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/leah-remini-scientology-documentary-ratings-1201930528/|author=Oriana Schwindt|publisher=variety.com|title=Leah Remini Scientology Doc Premiere Draws 2.1 Million Viewers for A&E | Variety |date= November 30, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2017}} ==See also== {{Portal|Scientology}} * [[Scientology and other religions]] * [[Scientology and sexual orientation]] * [[Space opera in Scientology]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Notes== {{Refbegin|30em}} * {{cite book|last=Barrett|first=David V.|title=Sects, 'Cults' & Alternative Religions: A World Survey and Sourcebook (Paperback) New Ed|publisher=Sterling Pub Co Inc|year=1998|isbn=978-0-7137-2756-2|ref=harv|postscript=}} * Behar, Richard (1991). {{nihongo|'''Shinichi Fujimura'''|藤村 新一|Fujimura Shin'ichi|b. 4 May 1950}} is a Japanese [[archaeology|archaeologist]] who claimed he had found a large number of stone artifacts dating back to the [[Lower Paleolithic]] and [[Middle Paleolithic]] periods. These objects were later revealed to be [[archaeological forgery|forgeries]].
==Success== Fujimura was born in [[Kami, Miyagi]], in 1950. After graduating from a high school in [[Sendai]], he obtained a job in a manufacturing company. He became intrigued by archaeology when he was a child, finding shards of [[Jōmon pottery]] in the backyard of his house.<ref name="netsuzo">''発掘捏造'', 毎日新聞旧石器遺跡取材班, [[Mainichi Shinbun|毎日新聞社]], 2001.</ref>
In 1972 Fujimura began to study archaeology and to look for Paleolithic [[artifact (archaeology)|artifact]]s during his holidays. Within the few years to follow, he rose to fame among amateur and academic archaeologists in [[Sendai]] by which he was appointed the head of the [[NGO]] group, ''Sekki Bunka Kenkyukai'' in 1975. Fujimura discovered and excavated many Paleolithic stone artifacts in Miyagi prefecture, such as at ''Zazaragi site'' in 1981, ''Nakamine C site'' in 1983 and ''Babadan A site'' in 1984. From a cross-dating investigation of the [[stratum]] these stone tools were estimated to be about 50,000 years old.
He established his reputation as a leading amateur archaeologist because he found most of the artifacts on his own.<ref name="netsuzo"/> He even became known as the archaeologist with the "divine hands".
After this success, he participated in 180 archaeological digs in northern Japan and almost always found artifacts, their age becoming increasingly older. Based on his discoveries the history of the [[Japanese Paleolithic]] period was extended to about 300,000 years. Most of the archaeologists did not question Fujimura's work and this discovery was written in the history [[textbook]]s. Later he gained a position as a deputy director at the private NGO group ''Tohoku Paleolithic Institute''.
==Criticism== Despite the acquiescence from the archeologists, some geologists and anthropologists claimed the discovery was dubious and lacked consistency with the geologic analysis of the sites.
Toshiki Takeoka at the [[Kyoritsu Women's University|Kyoritsu Joshi University]] published an article<ref>''『前期旧石器』とはどのような石器群か'', 旧石器考古学56, 石器文化談話会, 1998</ref>
{{quote|Stone artifacts which were recently discovered at Japanese Upper Paleolithic sites, such as ''Kamitakamori site'' are so different from the characteristics of these Upper Paleolithic stones. ... Those are the same as the stone shafts of the [[Jōmon period]] in their shape or fabrication method. ... This site and their archaeological finds are undoubtedly abnormal, a kind of [[OOPARTS]].}}
Shizuo Oda and Charles T. Keally also mentioned some peculiarities in their article<ref>(1986):''A Critical Look at the Palaeolithic and "Lower Palaeolithic" Research in Miyagi Prefecture.'', 人類学雑誌, vol. 94-3, 1986</ref>
{{quote|After talking to the principal investigators, Okamura and Kamata, and a thorough study of the relevant publications and the lithics themselves, we have concluded that no proven artifacts of human origin predating 30,000 B. P. exist in Miyagi prefecture. The claims of Okamura, Kamata, and some other Miyagi archaeologists that they have discovered a "Lower Palaeolithic" are based on flawed research and are dubious claims.}}
==Disclosure== On October 23, 2000, Fujimura and his team announced that they had another finding at the ''Kamitakamori site'' near [[Kurihara, Miyagi|Tsukidate town]]. The finds were estimated to be 570,000 years old.
On November 5, 2000, the newspaper ''[[Mainichi Shimbun]]'' published pictures of Fujimura digging holes and burying the artifacts his team later found. The pictures had been taken one day before the finding was announced. Fujimura admitted his forgery in an interview with the newspaper.
Fujimura confessed and apologized the same day in a press conference. He said that he had been "possessed by an uncontrollable urge".<ref name="netsuzo"/> He had planted the artifacts from his own collection in strata that would have indicated earlier dates. In Kamitakamori he had planted 61 of 65 artifacts, and had earlier planted all of the stonework in the [[Soshin Fudozaka]] site in [[Hokkaidō]]. He claimed that these were the only times he had planted artifacts.
The Japanese Archaeological Association disaffiliated Fujimura from its members. A special investigation team of the Association revealed that almost all the artifacts which he had found were his fabrication.
==Aftermath== In a series of articles in the Japanese magazine ''[[Shūkan Bunshun]]'' published on January 25,<ref>''「第二の神の手」が大分「聖嶽人」周辺にいる!? '', 週刊文春, 1月25日号</ref> February 1 and March 15, 2001, the magazine alleged that the stone tools discovered at the Hijiridaki cave site (聖嶽洞窟遺跡) in [[Ōita Prefecture]] had also been forgeries, and indicated that [[Mitsuo Kagawa]], a professor at [[Beppu University]], had been involved in that hoax. Kagawa committed suicide and left a suicide note in which he pleaded his innocence.
His family filed a defamation suit against ''Shūkan Bunshun'' the same year. The Ōita district Court and the Fukuoka High Court decided to order the magazine to pay the damages and issue an apology to the family of Kagawa. The magazine appealed to the [[Supreme Court of Japan]], although the appeal was rejected in September 2004. An apology statement was published in the September 2, 2004, issue.
==See also== * [[Japanese Paleolithic hoax]] * [[Piltdown Man]] * [[Beringer's Lying Stones]]
==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite journal|url=http://www.archaeology.org/0101/newsbriefs/godshands.html |title="God's Hands" Did the Devil's Work|last=Romey|first=Kristin M. |journal=Archeology|volume=54|issue=1|date=January–February 2001|accessdate=4 February 2013}} * {{cite journal|title=Japanese Fraud Highlights Media-Driven Research Ethic|last=Normile|first=Dennis|journal=Science|date=5 January 2001|volume=291|issue=5501|pages=34–55|doi=10.1126/science.291.5501.34}} * {{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.290.5494.1083b | title = Structural Failure | journal = Science | volume = 290 | issue = 5494 | pages = 1083b– | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }} * {{cite journal|title=Further fakes.|journal=Science|date=5 October 2001|volume=294|issue=5540|pages=31|doi=10.1126/science.294.5540.31c}} * {{cite journal|last=Normile |first=Dennis|date=November 2001 |title=Questions Arise Over Second Japanese Sit|journal=Science|volume=294|issue=5547|pages=1634|doi=10.1126/science.294.5547.1634a}} * {{cite book|last=Feder|first=Kenneth L.|authorlink=Kenneth Feder|title=[[Frauds, Myths, and Mysteries: Science and Pseudoscience in Archaeology]]|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill]]|location=New York|year=2008|isbn=0-07-340529-9}}
==External links== *[http://www.t-net.ne.jp/~keally/Hoax/how.html Japanese Archeology], Web page by C. T. Keally *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080301024031/http://wwwsoc.nii.ac.jp/jaa2/zenchuki/index.htm 前・中期旧石器問題関連文書総覧], 日本考古学協会
{{Authority control}}
